An industry in distress leads to the sorts of speeches that were made then and to inflamed passions. It is distressing to anyone who cares about this great Queensland industry to see that happen. What is needed in such a situation is not the sort of rubbish that we have just heard but a consideration on behalf of the people who have a responsibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Disprove it.
—Order, the honourable member for Capricornia!
—He does not worry me, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have seen enough of him for years.
—You never worry about a little fox terrier.

—No. The people who have to make the decisions in relation to this industry have a responsibility to defuse that sort of situation and to do the best they can for all parties to make sure that the industry stays strong.

SPEECH.PARA: Until about 30 minutes ago there was a sentiment abroad that we should have a bipartisan and wide ranging debate on the needs of the sugar industry. That is the sort of sentiment we need. What is needed at the moment is for this Government to be given a bit of a shove to get on and do some of the things it said in the last two election campaigns it was going to do for sugar. The sugar industry, of course, is not only a Queensland industry but is overwhelmingly a Queensland industry. In Australia it is a lean and superbly efficient industry, so it is not a question of rationalising the industry to make it more efficient or more profitable. It is a question of determining the factors that caused it to reach this stage of crisis, and what can be done in the short and long terms.

The sugar industry needs and deserves support. The reasons it needs support are partly domestic and partly international. The honourable member for Capricornia glossed over the European Economic Community's role in this. He made a few glib remarks about the structure of the industry in the EEC. He said that members of the EEC could well afford to pay the subsidies. We cannot afford subsidies of the kind paid by the EEC. The Government ought to be expressing as strongly as it can to the EEC its determination that, whatever happens with dumping on the international sugar market, Australia will stand by a great industry. It produces efficiently. Contrary to the impression which would be gained from the previous honourable member's speech, it has not begged for assistance at every turn during the last 20 years but has needed help on only two occasions. However, the great thing about this industry and one of the reasons it deserves support is that it does not go to the Government annually or every two years saying: 'What can you do for us next? We have been thinking about it since the last time you did something. Here is something else'. That has not been done by the sugar industry. Its record can be contrasted with that of few other industries in Australia. One of the great strengths of the sugar industry and one of the reasons it has operated as well as it has through the decades is its ability essentially to manage its own affairs. It is an industry which has gone in for a degree of self-control and self-regulation. But there is a limit to how far that will work. It has worked very well for most of this century. However, at the moment the pressures on the industry are enormous.

I have alluded briefly to the pressures from outside as a result of the EEC's dumping and subsidising policies. For a whole host of reasons this Government must show determination to the EEC in relation to the sugar industry. One of those reasons is what this industry contributes to Australia. All speakers in this debate have referred to the number of jobs which are directly involved in the sugar industry and the number of jobs that flow from the multiplier effect of this industry.

Reference has been made to the importance of the industry to major provincial centres in Queensland in particular. I have one of them in my electorate, namely the town of Beenleigh. With the great sections of the industry located in central and northern Queensland, people overlook the fact that the industry also operates in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales. There would be a widespread impact on the economies of many centres of Queensland and New South Wales if the industry were allowed to founder. It has been pointed out that the support this industry asks for now to be able to keep going in the immediate and troubled future is very small in comparison with what would have to come out of the taxpayers' pockets if the industry were allowed to decline to the point where a serious number of jobs were lost.

In the case of Beenleigh in my electorate this is particularly pointed because in that area it is a very finely tuned industry. So interdependent is it that, if that industry declines at all, virtually the lot of it will go. It is a phoney tactic for the honourable member for Capricornia, in that context, to try to play off miller against producer. The producers know very well that they need the millers, just as the millers acknowledge that they need the producers. Both sides are attempting to come up with a solution. They need to be aided and advised by government, government representatives and parliamentary representatives on what are the best ways to do it. Nothing is surer than that they will fail if they allow themselves to be divided. They will be conquered in two ways. They will be conquered by a government that cops out and says 'The industry cannot make up its mind so we will wash our hands of it', and they will be conquered by those economic forces supported by subsidies. It is not a fate that this industry deserves.

Both the domestic and international pressures have been very heavy. The cost of production versus returns to the grower are out of all proportion. I will quickly give a couple of figures on costs. In the last 10 years food prices in this country have risen by 292 per cent and wages by 428 per cent. The sugar industry, along with other primary industries, is feeling that pressure of declining income on the one hand, and increased wage costs on the other.

I have said before and I say again that this Government must absolutely resolutely resist the pressures being put on it by the EEC. It is nonsense to talk about an industry not being able to cope with market forces, when market forces are not operating, as they are not in the case of the international sugar industry. Other Australian industries care very much about the determination that the Hawke Government will show in relation to sugar. The dairy industry is one which faces the same sorts of pressures from dumping by the EEC and will also need the resolute support of the Hawke Government to remain viable in this country. Australia needs the sugar industry. It depends on its ability to trade and to sell internationally. In 1983-84 sugar was our eighth largest export commodity and earned $619m worth of our export income. We must support our export industries against subsidised pressures from outside.

As I and other speakers have said-I will not canvass all the figures again-the sugar industry is a major employer. It is economic sense for the Government to support the industry and to keep it going in a time of pressure when the alternative is unemployment, the costs of unemployment benefit and the resultant cost to the taxpayer. I hope that the Government and its members will not be tempted to say that we cannot afford it and that this money would come out of the taxpayers' dollar. In fact, this industry and its producers have been major subsidisers of the Australian consumer in past times. I remind the honourable member for Capricornia that within the last decade, during the life of the last Liberal-National Party Government, new arrangements were entered into in relation to the domestic sugar price. Previously the sugar industry had been prepared to subsidise the domestic consumer. When pressure came too heavily on international prices a rearrangement of the domestic sugar price was necessary. The Fraser Government and the sugar industry worked that out. I suggest that the honourable member for Capricornia should look at some of the literature and propaganda of that time when the sugar industry was in crisis. He would probably find the source of half his speech. He would find that people were attacking the sugar millers in those days too.

I want to refer briefly to the ethanol matter. The honourable member for Dawson made reference to ethanol in his speech. In debate in the other place much was made by an Australian Democrat senator of the possibilities for ethanol in the future. The honourable member for Dawson mentioned a number of those issues. Since that debate I have received a letter from the General Secretary of the Proprietary Sugar Millers Association Pty Ltd on the subject of ethanol. It is a very technical letter. It was circulated to all Queensland senators and probably to other honourable members. I seek leave to table the letter so that it can be a public document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That letter is available to honourable members who would like to look at the more technical side of ethanol and see that it is not the panacea that some might suggest it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I ought to remind honourable members of the actions that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as Leader of the Australian Labor Party, and the Minister for Primary Industry, as the primary industry spokesman, said the sugar producers could look forward to. After all, it was the sugar producers who caught the cane train to Brisbane and who met with the Prime Minister during the last election campaign. They went away believing that action would be taken by a Hawke Government. In public meetings in north Queensland during the 1983 election campaign the sugar producers met the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry and believed that pressures on their industry would receive relief under a Hawke Government. The term 'sympathetic consideration' was used by both Mr Hawke and Mr Kerin. I do not bring in this matter to put down in any way the things the honourable member for Herbert has said. I hope the sympathy he has for the sugar industry is such that he can persuade the Minister and the Prime Minister to share that sympathy. In 1983 there were hopes raised of industry loans and/or an indemnity scheme. In 1984 there were hopes raised of a fixed floor price. So far there has not been much movement. I point out that in the life of this Government the steel industry has received $176m in assistance; the car industry $150m in assistance and the sugar industry $16m in assistance. It has been suggested, uncharitably, that that $16m might not have been forthcoming if there had not been twice that much forthcoming from the Queensland Government, which the honourable member for Capricornia so viciously attacked a short time ago. Not only the present State Government but also, of course, the previous Queensland governments were attacked by him.

To advance the debate it is necessary that pressure be kept up by producers, and sugar millers whose livelihoods are also at stake, and by those sympathetic to the sugar industry. It is necessary that the Hawke Government be reminded of promises it has made in two election campaigns of assistance to the sugar industry which is yet to be forthcoming. I think first and foremost it is necessary that the industry and its problems be debated objectively. I hope that in the rest of this debate we will see an illumination not only of the sugar industry's problems but also of possible solutions. I hope-I trust not in vain-that at the end of the debate the Minister will be able to give some better indication than the industry has had so far of action that is to the point for the benefit of this great industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my remarks by indicating that I come to this place with some knowledge and some direct appreciation of the sugar region. I have lived in a sugar growing industry for the major part of my life. Apart from that, I have been directly involved in the administration of the Queensland legislation. I say at the outset that the Queensland legislation is the predominant set of patterns for the sugar industry. The only role the Federal legislation has in relation to the industry is what we are talking about in this place today, and that is the domestic agreement. For some years I was the Chairman of the Mossman Sugar Cane Prices Board and I am aware of the intricacies and the problems that now exist within that industry. The industry has had a very chequered pattern. No one in this House today has spoken about the cyclical nature of the industry, a pattern which has existed within the industry for quite a number of decades. Of course, any support, any legislation which could overcome those difficulties, rests squarely at the feet of the Queensland Government. In saying that, I do not suggest that the Federal Government should not be party to an attempt to reverse the situation existing in the sugar industry today.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one major problem. It is very refreshing to hear today what I believe to be a new approach from the Opposition benches in relation to the sugar industry. About two years ago the relevant Minister quite unequivocally indicated-in fact, he did it in Mackay in north Queensland, in the heart of the sugar industry-that the Federal Government of the day would not give any assistance to the sugar industry, short term or otherwise. Mr Nixon made that quite clear. It was on that basis that the then shadow Minister, Mr Kerin, who, as I have often indicated in this place, is recognised as the Bob Hawke of the bush, indicated he would sympathetically look at the difficulties of the industry. Little did we realise that the industry was in such turmoil internally that it had to be reviewed. I ask those opposite: Where is the machinery for the internal review of the industry? It rests in State legislation, not in Federal legislation. On that basis this Government has set about attempting to assist the industry.

We have heard figures bandied around here today. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), was the last to do so. Unfortunately for those of us here, for those who are listening or who might see those figures in the media, they are totally incorrect. I suppose the next speaker will get up and use the Queensland National Party figures as well. If there is any criticism in what I am saying now, it is directed at the Queensland National Party, because for two years all it has done is use the sugar industry as a political football. It is interesting to note that when it does so, quite strangely-I do not know whether there is any coincidence-it is just before an election, be it State or Federal. Before the 1983 Federal election the Queensland Government and the coalition Federal Government said absolutely nought about the difficulties of the sugar industry in Queensland. They did not want to know about them. But because there was a coalition government here the Queensland Government did not raise the issue at election time. When was it first raised? It was raised in October 1984 or earlier, when there was a State election, Mr Ahern, then the Minister for Primary Industries, bandied these National Party figures throughout the length and breadth of Queensland. Most of them were false. It is unfortunate that those who have spoken on the other side have not made the effort to get accurate figures of the assistance that has been forthcoming to the sugar industry in the last 24 months.

The last speaker said in the vicinity of $32m has been given to the Queensland sugar industry by the Queensland Government over the last two years. That is incorrect, to the extent that the Queensland Cane Growers Council, a non-political body involved in the industry, has put out a bulletin ridiculing the Queensland Government for the misuse of improper and inaccurate figures. In effect the Queensland Government was saying, through Mr Ahern, its spokesman, that it gave $10m to the Co-operative Sugar Millers Association. In fact it did, but after it had transferred it in a phoney way from the Rural Reconstruction Board into Consolidated Revenue, and then paid it out to the co-operative sugar millers. Not only did it defraud the people of Queensland and attempt to indicate to the sugar industry that it was assistance directed from it, but also it bumped up the interest rate from the 8 per cent at which the funds were gained from the Commonwealth Government to 14.5 per cent. The Queensland Government is doing this all the time. At a Federal level we are giving the Queensland Government holiday interest payment conditions; that is, for two years we do not seek interest on moneys loaned to the Queensland Government. It does not pass that on to the sugar industry. It does not pass on the moratorium or the interest holiday. It does not even pass on the interest rate at which it gets the money; it bumps it up and fills its own coffers.

I say this with no criticism of those opposite but with total and firm criticism of the Queensland Government. It has been stated here today that any approach to the problems of the sugar industry must be on a bilateral basis and I do not disagree with that, but I go one step further and say that it must be on a tripartite basis. It is not only the Opposition and the Government here which must attempt to overcome the difficulties of the industry, it is also the Queensland Government, and that is where the whole thing falls down. I shall quote once again from a document-I know the next speaker has a copy of this and he will confirm what I say-from the Queensland Cane Growers Council. As I have said before, it is not into party politics; it is there for the interest, the benefit and the welfare of the sugar industry. This document indicates what Mr Soper had to say at a meeting that he and Mr Belcher, the Secretary of the Queensland Cane Growers Council, attended with the Premier of Queensland:
The QCGC--
that is the Queensland Cane Growers Council--
was anxious to discuss recent developments concerning the plight of growers with the leader of the Queensland Government.
Unfortunately, that is Mr Bjelke-Petersen. The document continues:
He also referred to . . . public comments by the Premier following the recent rally of canegrowers in Brisbane. It was suggested that the attached agenda--
that was to go to the Premier--
might be an appropriate means of methodically dealing with the subjects which the Council desired to discuss with the Premier.

It was after discussion with the Federal Government that the Council saw fit to speak to the Queensland Government. There is a feeling within the cane growing industry in Queensland that it is a waste of time attempting to do any business to get any assistance for the future of the sugar industry from the Queensland Government. The Premier made the observation:
'nice guys always get taken for a ride and you--
that is the QCGC--
have been far too nice in your approach to the Prime Minister who has used that to advantage to get himself off the hook'.
Mr Soper's report continues:

The Premier elaborated on the importance of seeing problems of this magnitude against the prevailing political background and said that he would have liked to have accompanied the deputation to Messrs Hawke and Kerin.

There is no doubt about the modus operandi of the Premier. He wants to make the issue political and he proved that during the campaigns of the last Federal and Queensland State elections. That is the problem, and it is not a bilateral approach that will succeed, it is a tripartite one. If the Queensland Government is not prepared to come to the party-it has the machinery of the workings of the sugar industry-all the rhetoric, the propositions and the goodwill that this place might have will go nowhere. I will talk later about the Premier because he has been the major stumbling block in any possible negotiation between the Federal and State governments to come to some arrangement for the future benefit, welfare and restructuring of the sugar industry.

During my time in this place-I know I speak on behalf of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay)-I have been involved in long and tedious negotiations with our Government in putting forward propositions from the industry. It is very pleasing at times to gain the support and commendation of the industry. Mr Keith Day, the Senior Vice-President of the Queensland Cane Growers Council, gave me a public commendation as a result of the negotiations which took place after the bringing down of the Industries Assistance Commission report, at which time I fought for the retention of the embargo, notwithstanding the recommendations contained in the IAC report. I also recall very clearly discussions in relation to the lifting of dumping duties on nitrogenous fertilisers. On that occasion the honourable member for Herbert and I were involved in lengthy negotiations, at the conclusion of which Mr Belcher once again commented on the assistance and help which was forthcoming from both the honourable member for Herbert and me.

Now that we have in truthful perspective-I emphasise that it is in truthful perspective; I will be interested to hear what the next speaker has to say and whether he starts bandying around the National Party's false figures again-what assistance has been given to the sugar industry during the last two years, we see that, out of the $30m that has been given to the industry, barely $1m has come from the Queensland Government. It is unfortunate that the Premier of that State has seen fit once again in the heat of an election campaign to use public funding to put out false pamphlets which he cannot substantiate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite untrue.
—Totally untrue, and I note that the honourable member for Capricornia is aware of the presence of that false document as well.
—He would have an objective view, too!

—We will hear from the honourable member. He brings to this place a lot of experience in the sugar industry! He has overseen the great development of the sugar industry in the Northern Territory during his time as Chief Minister! I will be interested to hear what he says. He would not know how to cut a stick of cane. He would not have a clue. I think he should stick to that issue rather than having to suffer a defeat in his Party room in trying to float a new State in north Queensland. The most junior man in his Party room knocked him over in a debate on the formation of a great new State in north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving that aside, I say that this Bill that we are now debating is welcomed by the industry. There is no evidence to indicate that the industry is not satisfied with it. I commend the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) for his foresight in rejecting, in effect, the IAC recommendations. The rejection of those recommendations was quite unequivocal not only by the Minister for Primary Industry but also by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Bill is supported by the industry and by the Government. In relation to the amendment to the motion for the second reading which was moved by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), it was obvious from what occurred in the other place that the industry as a whole would be discussed during the debate on this Bill. It is merely political posturing to move such a self-centred and self-serving amendment as the one that is before us now. I make no further comment in relation to that amendment.

In conclusion, I believe there is only one way in which we can come out of the end of the tunnel-if there is any light at the end of the tunnel-and that is by implementing a bilateral approach in this place. I repeat what I have so often said during my remarks today: It must be supported by a Queensland Government. No support from the Queensland Government to this date has been forthcoming, which is a sad state of affairs when Mr Soper went to see the Premier of Queensland in early 1984 to discuss with him the desperate plight of the sugar industry. That meeting took place, and that cannot be denied. That was in early 1984. In November 1984, some five months later, the Premier of Queensland told the cane growers in Cairns that he was unaware of the plight of the sugar industry. He deliberately misled the people of Queensland. I appeal today to honourable members opposite to approach the Premier of Queensland before he travels too far down that accelerating path of senility so that he will sit down and talk with the Federal Government about the problems in the industry and not merely use it as a political football.

Had it been debated, one of my arguments on the topic would have been that it was another promise that the Australian Labor Party dishonoured while it was in government in Queensland many years ago. —What has this to do with the Bill?

—Tell us how much.

—The honourable member for Capricornia is still protesting. He spoke with an air of complete desperation. He harked back to Dr Rex Patterson. —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Prior to the honourable member's speech a member of the Opposition took a point of order and chastised me for referring to John McEwen. What is the normal ruling? Is there a consistency in rulings on this matter?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The former member for Dawson has an enormous school of followers in the Northern Territory. However, as I said, he retired from politics a deeply embittered man. —The charlatan on the other side is still shouting. I think it was in 1983 when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:

The contribution of North Queensland to Australia's wealth and stability has always been high, but it has rarely received a fair return for its contribution to the national wealth, and a proper recognition of its strategic position. TALK.START.PARA: —What about them?
—What has happened to the promises? The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: National governments have to attend to the long term prosperity of the towns and cities of North Queensland.

I agree with him 100 per cent. He said that we have an obligation to the half million or so north Queenslanders and those other Australians who will come to live there in the years to come. The Prime Minister continued:
We have an obligation to deal with important regions on a regional, as well as a national basis.

They are fine and fair words but they are soon forgotten. Even as far back as 1982 the Australian Labor Party recognised that there were problems in the sugar industry. When in opposition the Australian Labor Party put out a very attractive document which, I am sure, lured lots of people in north Queensland to vote for the Australian Labor Party. What did it say about the Australian sugar industry in 1982? The Australian Labor Party policy stated:
The Australian sugar industry faces problems on three counts: price, costs and structure.
Prices have dropped due to:
(1) World production being 10 per cent above demand and rising . . .
(2) The EEC is dumping subsidised sugar on world markets.
(3) The United States of America has imposed quotas and is encouraging local sugar production.
(4) Brazil's ethanol program . . .
(5) High fructose corn syrup poses a long term threat to sugar . . .
(6) Costs are rising because of fuel prices . . .

As any primary producer and many other around this country would say, costs are still rising due to increases in fuel prices. What has this Government done about it? Interest rates and machinery prices are on the up and up again. There are structural problems. The document then continued with a description of the Australian Labor Party policy. I understand that this policy was announced in Townsville by Senator Button. The Australian Labor Party policy of 1982, during the current crisis, stated:
. . . special accommodation for an industry loan will be sympathetically examined.

What has happened since 1982 by way of Federal assistance to the sugar industry? In March 1983 we saw this Government elected. Fair words to the north Queenslanders got it seats. In December 1984 the Government went to the people again without having done anything of substance whatsoever for the sugar industry. It has still not done anything for the sugar industry.

All that has been done to date-as best I can ascertain-is that the Prime Minister has agreed to meet the Premier of Queensland on 1 April. I certainly hope that that meeting on All Fools Day will not mean that people in the industry will be treated like fools again by this Government, as happened after the 1983 and 1984 promises regarding assistance to the industry.

As I understand the position of the Government now, as stated by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) at the annual general meeting of the Proprietary Sugar Millers Association Pty Ltd, growers and millers must first agree on a joint position. That is virtually asking for and expecting the impossible. The Minister for Primary Industry knows as well as I do that there are intrinsic differences between the interests of growers and millers. As the Queensland Cane Growers Association Chairman, Fred Soper, said:
If governments continue to delay urgently needed assistance to growers, pending industry consensus, both sectors--
this is the growers and millers--
will have one major problem in common-they will both be out of business.

The situation is so serious that it should not be played around with any more. We do not want to use the sugar industry as a political football. We are not using the industry as a political football but are demanding that this Government honour some of the many promises made to this industry. For example, the growers were promised a floor price scheme. In response to cane growers at Giru south of Townsville the Ministers for Primary Industry 10 days before the last election promised that the Labor Party, if re-elected, would introduce a floor price scheme. What has happened? Nothing has happened.

It is estimated that it would cost $80m to assist the industry by establishing a floor price scheme to keep people on the land and to maintain jobs and regional economies. The Government is likely to have to fork our a lot more money than that in social security payments in the very near future unless it does something about that scheme very quickly. So far the Government has come up with a paltry $16m in assistance, in sharp contrast to the bounty arrangements for the steel industry which are expected to cost $52m this year alone or the $150m worth of assistance to the car industry. Of course, the difference is in votes. There are not as many votes in Queensland as there are in the more populous and industralised south. Last night in this House the honourable member for Herbert highlighted the raw deal administered to the North by this Government when he spoke of the funding allocation under the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The allocation of funding under CSIRO is simply illustrative of the way funding is not allocated to the North under this Government.

The people in the sugar industry, who have contributed some $300m in export earnings to the Australian economy, are no less deserving in times of hardship than are people in the steel and car industries. They are Australians, and all the time one hears about building a more equitable Australia. It reminds me of what happened in history some 200 years ago when a mob in Paris marched out to Versailles to demand bread of King Louis and Queen Marie Antoinette. We all know the story. When the mob gathered under the Queen's balcony, she is reported as saying: 'Let them eat cake'. The Prime Minister is always talking about working to build a more equitable Australia. Just before the last election he was in Bundaberg, a centre that depends a great deal on the sugar industry and an area on which the downturn has had a serious effect. The people and farmers in Bundaberg have been as resourceful as they can and have diversified as much as they can. When the Prime Minister was asked 'What assistance are you going to give us here in Bundaberg?' his reply-his contribution to building a more equitable Australia-was: 'Let them grow vegetables'. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by complimenting the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), the only Labor member who spoke in this debate in a positive and constructive fashion. I was wholly disappointed with the comments of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and also the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) on this important piece of legislation, the Sugar Agreement Bill 1985. The honourable member for Leichhardt seemed to be preoccupied with casting personal aspersions against the Premier of Queensland and in distorting the true situation in the sugar industry. Let me take up his assertion concerning the marketing arrangements that prevail, or do not prevail, in the sugar industry. Perhaps the honourable member feels somewhat guilty that the Labor Government, a government of which he is part, has dismantled the only support scheme that was available to the sugar industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be recalled that the previous coalition Government introduced the income equalisation deposit scheme-a scheme that was of considerable benefit to the sugar industry, an industry with a record of variable incomes. But what has this Government done? It has totally dismantled that scheme and made it useless and ineffective for this industry. The honourable member for Leichhardt said that the former coalition Government had not done anything to introduce a marketing scheme for the industry. The coalition Government did nothing because the industry made no request for anything to be done. The industry is basically self-reliant and by a process of continual adjustment it had adjusted to changing market and economic circumstances. The coalition does not bring in socialist-oriented philosophies to socialise an industry at a whim. We would introduce a marketing scheme only with the agreement of the industry. I emphasise that when we were in government the industry made no such request.

The matter before the House is most important and needs a constructive approach. The problem in the sugar industry is not of its own making but originates overseas in the European Economic Community. It is the direct result of the common agricultural policy and the policy of the European Common Market in dumping excessive sugar production on world markets, distorting those markets and depressing the prices. It must be remembered that the Australian industry is efficient and significant. It involves some 6,600 cane growers between Grafton and Cairns, and produces some 3 million tonnes of raw sugar a year. That makes Australia the fourth largest sugar producer in the world. The industry employs 20,000 people directly and 100,000 people indirectly, and some 200,000 people depend on the industry. In the past decade the industry has earned 4.6 per cent of Australia's export income. If one examines Australia's recent balance of payments, it will be seen how important is export income to this country. The industry has achieved all this in what in recent years has been a hostile economic environment-particularly in the past two years in which the industry has faced high and rising costs, and has had to confront regulated labour markets and high and exorbitant costs as a result of tariffs and quotas. The present Government, in its short term in office-which will not be for much longer, I am sure-has acted to exacerbate the problems of this industry by further entrenching the privileged positions of the labour unions, by increasing costs, by indexing labour rates, and by providing further assistance to secondary industry by way of tariffs and quotas, which add indirectly to the costs of primary industry, export industries and the sugar industry.

The sugar industry of Australia has supported our consumers in the period between 1974-75 and 1981-82 by providing sugar to the domestic market at below world prices. I am told that in real terms the effective benefit of that subsidy to Australian consumers has been some $408m. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics recognises the industry's difficulties and sees no prospect of an immediate increase in prices available to the sugar industry in the next couple of years, but it believes this is a short term problem. It is important in terms of the size and significance of this industry to the Australian economy that the Government recognise that we cannot afford to close down the industry. One is not talking merely of growing cane in eastern Australia, but one is dealing with people. One is talking of 6,600 cane farmers and their families, as well as the mill workers and their families.

What are the consequences of closing down sugar towns? In the part of Australia that I come from we are not totally dependent on the sugar industry, but it is a very significant industry. If the mill at Condong is to be closed down, the impact on the town of Murwillumbah will be great. It is true that the area has a tourist industry, the cattle industry and other industries to fall back on, but I believe that if that mill were to be closed it would knock 25 per cent off the economic activity of Murwillumbah. Other towns, such as Ballina and Grafton, would be similarly affected. In Queensland the situation is far worse. There are towns such as Tully which are virtually totally dependent on the sugar industry.

It is all very well for the Government to react when the steel industry and the steel workers complain about their problems when they come here to Canberra and protest-Wollongong is close to Canberra and those workers can afford to get here-but the Queensland sugar farmers cannot afford to travel down here and are not of a mind to come here and protest violently. They believe the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he says that this Government governs for all Australia. They are expecting him to honour his commitments made in two election campaigns. Perhaps that is the reason why the honourable member for Capricornia and the honourable member for Leichhardt have reacted so strongly on a personal level in this debate.

The plain fact is that during the 1983 election campaign the then shadow Minister and now Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said that a Labor government would provide an underwriting scheme or loan assistance to the sugar industry. That was said in March 1983. Since then we have had another election campaign and in the course of that campaign in 1984 the Prime Minister said that the industry would benefit from 'meaningful' assistance. I think that word should be redefined to be meaningless in terms of the present Government, because it has done nothing. The honourable member for Herbert recognises the need for immediate action. I agree with many of his comments, but I am concerned that the Government is not moving fast enough to provide the assistance required by the industry. He suggested that an inquiry was now taking place that would report by 1986. That is too far away for my neighbours. My neighbours are cane farmers, I live in a sugar-producing area, and in 1986 they will be bankrupt-there will be mortgagee in possession sales in my area and in Queensland. The consequences of that and the social disruption will be massive. We need more immediate action, a rational approach and short term help. In the past rural industries in Australia have encountered short term market and economic problems. In the past the wool industry has suffered. I can remember days when sheep were referred to as ground lice and all sorts of people-perhaps they were members of the Australian Labor Party-were suggesting that the industry be phased out and eliminated. The coalition Government provided assistance and we now have a strong, viable wool industry earning export dollars for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —With short term assistance.

—With short term assistance. In 1974 there was a crisis in the cattle industry. Again, the coalition Government came to the assistance of that industry and we now have a strong and viable beef industry earning export income for Australia. The sugar industry has the potential to come out of this crisis and earn important export industry income once again for Australia. Heaven only knows we need it because we are rapidly losing our international competitiveness under the policies of this Government. What the issue really comes down is that this Government must honour its undertaking to provide assistance to the sugar industry. Just as the Government has provided assistance to the steel industry and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and just as it has provided assistance to the car industry, it must provide assistance not only to the sugar industry but also to the people involved in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be realistic about the sugar industry. Obviously world circumstances are changing, economic pressures are changing, and there will be a need for adjustment in the sugar industry. I do not deny that. I am sure that the honourable member for Herbert also recognises that need, as do my colleagues on my side of the House. Some people who are currently involved in the sugar industry will not continue in that industry and there will be a need to assist them and their families to leave it with dignity and to ensure that what capital can be rescued from the industry will be available for reinvestment and will be ploughed back into Australia for the benefit of Australia and those individuals. The Government must also provide assistance for those people who are stronger and have the resources and the capital behind them to continue in the industry. This Government must face up to the need to address this problem constructively in two ways: It must help people who need help to leave the industry and it must help those who can stay in the industry to do so for the long term, and this has to be done.

The Government has proposed that there be a sugar summit. A previous speaker said that it will be held on April Fools Day. I certainly hope that the Government will go out of its way to ensure that there is nothing foolish in its approach to the sugar industry and that those involved in the sugar industry of this country are not treated as fools. The importance of the industry must be recognised. The separate needs of the cane growing and milling industries must be recognised. The Government must come up with a proposal to assist the industry which will provide it with a long term future and which will also provide immediate assistance for the families affected by its problems.

I believe that what this industry needs is a commitment from the Government to provide a guaranteed price, a minimum average price, for cane based on $240 per tonne for raw sugar. That price would allow cane growers currently in the industry who have a commitment to remain in the industry to stay there. It will not allow them to buy new harvesters. It will not allow them to replace any of their current capital equipment, but it will keep them in the industry and it will provide a basic level of income for their families. It will allow them to keep their children at school. People do not recognise the consequences which flow from a sugar industry in crisis.

I will take the case of a typical sugar farm, which is a family farm, the basis of Australian agriculture. It generally consists of a father, mother and children. When the industry is in crisis, what happens? The family must earn extra income. There is a choice. Can the parents afford to keep their children at school or will they have to take them out of school and somehow try to find work for them? Heaven only knows where they will find it. Unemployment in most of the cane growing areas throughout Australia is high enough. It would be extremely difficult to put teenage children, children who could continue at school, on to the labour market. If these children are to find gainful employment they will probably have to leave the community in which they have grown up and go to another place to earn income and perhaps remit their income to their families.

We could have the situation where a cane farmer feels that his farm is no longer viable and he has to find other employment. Perhaps a wife will have to find work. She may have to go and work in a hospital, take domestic work, work as a cleaner or in a bar or do something else. What sort of impact would that have on a family with young children? These are the real problems of the sugar industry. They are not the statistical problems; they are the human problems that have to be addressed by this Government. The Government's reaction to these problems has to be sympathetic. There was a sympathetic response to the human problems of the steel industry. There was a sympathetic response to the human problems of the car industry. I am still waiting for a sympathetic response to the human problems of the sugar industry. We had promises in 1983 and in 1984. We will have D Day on 1 April, and it will be interesting to see what this Government will do. It must have a positive approach. In addition to providing some sort of guaranteed level of income for farmers, this Government needs to contribute additional funding for research because, as I have said, there will be adjustments in the sugar industry. Maybe we will have to look at producing sugar more efficiently. We are efficient now. We have doubled our productivity in the past 60 years but it can probably be further increased. Maybe we will have to find alternative crops or alternative land uses for the coastal alluvial plains. This will not be done without support from this Government and it will not be done without appropriate scientific research.

We have to look at providing reconstruction assistance for the sugar industry to ensure that those people who remain in it have the financial backing to restructure their debts and acquire the extra acreages that will probably be needed to make sure that their cost of production remains low and world competitive. We have to make sure that there is a sympathetic approach to the provision of social welfare for those who are leaving the industry. This Government would be well advised to look at how assistance is provided. Unemployment benefit should be provided for people who are leaving the industry and household support should be provided for people in the industry who are currently restructuring and readjusting.

I cannot stress too strongly the need for immediate action. We have been waiting since March 1983. The farms of neighbours living at either side of me, day by day, are increasingly showing the consequences of a depressed economic situation and earn virtually nil income. I see also the consequences this will have for their children. It is sad that a wife and mother has to leave three-year-old and four-year-old children in care and go out to find work because her husband still has to maintain the farm and keep the drains clear. We need a reaction from this Government and a statement that it will provide the assistance required to ensure that this industry continues into the future, restructured although it may have to be, that it continues to earn export income for Australia and that it continues to offer employment and to act as an economic engine for the coastal areas of north-eastern Australia. The Government must also provide assistance for those people who will not be able to continue in the sugar industry.

One final matter I must address is the capacity of this industry to help itself. In far northern New South Wales there are three co-operative sugar mills. They were taken over some years ago by the industry when CSR Ltd decided that it would not continue in that part of the world. The industry got together on a co-operative basis and ensured that those mills and the sugar industry in far northern New South Wales would continue. The industry has helped itself. It has contributed to its own viability and future. It is not too much to ask this Government to take the industry's problems seriously and act immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join previous speakers from this side of the House in congratulating the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) for the call to his Government to issue some measure of support to the ailing sugar industry. I trust that he will have some influence on other members of the Government. Unfortunately, there is not much cane grown in Bourke Street or Pitt Street. I also agree with the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) that there was no need for the hysterical contribution, or should I say non-contribution, to this debate of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). His confrontationist style contributed to his demise in Queensland politics before his transfer to this sphere of politics, and he still has not learnt.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Capricornia stated that the Queensland Government charges a margin of interest in excess of the interest rate levied by the Federal Government in funds advanced to that State. I remind the honourable member for Capricornia and this House that all funds must be repaid in full to the Federal Government, and with interest. It is the State Government alone which must carry the total risk at a time when this debate suggests that those risks are exceedingly high. Let the Federal Government advance its funds to the State and take 50 per cent of the risk. Then the Queensland Government could advance those funds on equal interest rates.

This Bill seeks a continuance of the prohibition on the import of sugar and certain sugar products into Australia and introduces a new formula to bring domestic price movements more directly in line with world prices. The new formula provides for the maximum price for bulk refined sugar of manufacturers grade to be adjusted every six months. The formula takes into consideration the consumer price index and the world market price for sugar. It is a recognition by the Government that the Australian sugar consumers have received a net transfer of payments from the sugar industry over the past decade in excess of $400 million. Unlike the position in the European community, the price of sugar to consumers in Australia cannot be used to subsidise the export price. Whereas in Australia the home consumption of sugar is less than 25 per cent of total production and the balance is available for export, the European percentages are almost the reverse. This Bill will, to some extent, introduce a mechanism to redress the past imbalance of home consumption prices which were well below world market prices for so many years.

Unfortunately, no measure is contained in this Bill to offer major support to the ailing cane sugar industry and the Government continues to ignore the plight of that industry. This Labor Government has displayed an almost arrogant animosity to the primary industries in Australia and is seemingly prepared to see the sugar industry decimated through an adherence to a world parity pricing philosophy which is unreasonable, unsound and ill-conceived-a trilogy which is demoralising to the growers and threatens the livelihood of so many families. It is not only the sugar growers and millers who in the end will have to bear the full brunt of this Government's refusal to introduce a meaningful support price for the industry. If the members of this Government will not consider the plight of the growers themselves, they should in all conscience consider the peril inherent in its policies to the employees dependent on the industry. It has been estimated by various agencies that a minimum of 100,000 and up to 200,000 employees could be affected in addition to the 6,600 producers and the 20,000 people directly employed in the sugar industry.

In the Hinkler electorate the livelihood and aspirations of almost 50,000 of my constituents hinge on the viability of the sugar cane industry. I am concerned for their future. Already the unemployment levels are at least twice the national average, and the position is worsening daily. Like Henry Lawson, although our basic beliefs could be considered to be opposing, my heart aches too for the owners of those sad faces in the street-the demoralised victims of the sugar recession. Daily I am confronted by the problems facing retrenched constituents in the Hinkler electorate, and the subsequent loss of human dignity, in what seems to them an unfeeling response by this Government to the situation. These people are mostly honest, previously hard-working family men who now cannot meet the family responsibilities. They too are depressed and feel they have reached the end of the road. This should not be allowed to happen. They might be on a roundabout with all exit lanes closed but the Government has the capacity to reopen the route through compassionate measures designed to support the sugar industry.

I call on the Government to heed the plea of growers, millers and the work force for an interim support plan. Not to do so now will be a folly of major dimension. For this Government not to respond in the meaningful way will forever be to the shame of the Australian Labor Party which in the beginning was born from the workers in primary production under that tree of knowledge at Longreach. The greater number of workers in the sugar industry are members of the Australian Workers Union. I call on that union and other unions, whose members inevitably will be affected, to put the well being of their members before any misguided party political subjugation of their duty to members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Hinkler will have the opportunity to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

—I ask the Attorney-General a question concerning the authentication of the Age New South Wales Police tapes and the granting of indemnities to the police officers involved in the making of the tapes to resolve the dilemma caused by conflicting advice given to him by Mr Temby and Mr Justice Stewart. I ask the Attorney-General: Is not the real cause of his dilemma the fact that the transcripts of the tapes reveal that on 9 February 1980, at the time of investigations into the alleged Cessna-Milner drug case conspiracy, and at the time of other alleged criminal activities revealed by the tapes, he had a meeting, albeit an innocent one, with one of the alleged principal conspirators? Is not this the classic case of the appearance of a conflict of interest from which an Attorney-General should completely divorce himself? Will the Attorney-General therefore undertake not to make decisions on this matter personally, but request the Solicitor-General or some other independent officer to exercise the discretion to avoid even the suggestion of a conflict of interest?

—There is no conflict of interest on my part. I acknowledge that Morgan Ryan saw me on a number of occasions, as he did the former honourable member for Phillip, Mr Birney, who was a member of the honourable gentleman's government at the time.
—That doesn't change anything.

—That does not change anything, but the reason for the interview related to whether a no bill should be filed. The honourable gentleman was the Attorney-General at the time and would know of representations made in that respect. I know nothing about the case in question to which he now refers. It is significant that at the time which the honourable gentleman mentions, 1980, the Fraser Government was in office. It is significant that what are alleged to be tapes and transcripts of tapes were all made between 1976 and 1981. It is also significant that they were made as a result of Australian Federal Police talking to State police, getting evidence of interception and, in fact, paying an informant money. All those matters are now matters of record as a result of Mr Temby's report. It certainly highlights the fact that the honourable gentleman, if not himself, certainly through his Attorney in the same Cabinet, would have been aware of a lot of information that was made available to the Federal Police at that time. If he now shakes his head and indicates that he does not know, I am astounded, because the evidence is very clear. It was known between 1976 and 1981. It was made clear to Sir Colin Woods, the Commissioner of Police. It was made clear to Inspector Lamb. It was known that the informant was called Hawthorn and that he was paid money for this interception. The difficulty we now have is that the New South Wales Police, if you look at Federal Police evidence, obviously committed a breach of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. There were no prosecutions lodged. Perhaps there was insufficient evidence to warrant a prosecution. The difficulty that the honourable gentleman is raising relates to matters solely within his own period of office, basically within his own period and it relates to information-
—It is for you to exercise the discretion.
—It is not a question of discretion. I am in this position--
—I am asking you about 1980.
—Yes, and the honourable gentleman was in office at the time. I am telling you about 1980. I am telling you about the illegal interceptions--
—He wasn't even a Minister in 1980.

—I meant when the Fraser Government was in office. Is that a problem? Do not tell me that honourable members did not know that Senator Durack was the Attorney-General at the time. How stupid can they get? One day they might make a statement as to what authority they had to use public money to pay an informant knowing he was breaching a Federal law. They might think about that. The problem that I now face relates to a conflict of advice, not to a conflict of interest.
—It must if you met the man yourself.
—I met the man, the same as anybody else would have met the man.
—I would not admit to 1980. The issue we are talking about is the honourable member's knowledge and the fact that the man--
—But we are talking about you.
—Order!
—The period we are talking about relates to a period when he was in office.
—Mr Speaker, if you want to give advice, tell him to sit down.

—Perhaps honourable members opposite would prefer that I sat down. The dilemma relates to the fact that 31 New South Wales police apparently breached the Federal Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Therefore, that renders them liable to punitive action. Not only that, they passed the information on to Federal Police, and that certainly relates to the question. I see no reason why those New South Wales police officers cannot do their duty and just tell the truth. That is all they have to do. They are not above the law. Nobody can give an exemption, particularly to law enforcement officers, on the basis of their having licence to do what they like, even though they break the law. The issue for them is very clear. They should do what they were asked to do by Mr Justice Stewart and tell him the facts. When will they do it? Mr Temby, QC, advises me that they are not entitled to an indemnity, and he is the Director of Public Prosecutions. The honourable gentleman talks about conflict of interest. Those officers are not entitled to indemnity merely because they are police. In fact, they are not entitled to indemnity, particularly because they are police. They have a duty to disclose any offence within their knowledge. They had a duty to do something about it when they were aware of it between 1976 and 1981 and on that basis, if they do their duty, there will be no problems with which the honourable gentleman is now so concerned. The previous Government, of which the honourable member was a member, had all this knowledge at the time and did nothing about it.
—But you have a question before you now. It has nothing to do with that.

—I have not desisted from trying to do my duty, which is to suggest again to the New South Wales police that they revise their attitude that they want an indemnity and that they give all the information to Mr Justice Stewart. Whether they will be prosecuted is another matter. The matter Mr Justice Stewart is investigating is their knowledge of crime and criminal activities arising from an alleged transcript and tapes. It is another matter of record, of course, that copies of the tapes and transcripts were also within the possession of the Liberal member for Northcott. He said he had received them from the New South Wales Liberal Party headquarters.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. I refer the Minister to the B-MAC transmission system. Will the Minister explain the likely benefits of the Government's decision to use the new B-MAC transmission system in association with Australia's new telecommunications satellites?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Isaacs for his question. In September 1984, following an extensive review of transmission systems, it was decided to adopt the B-MAC system to deliver Australian Broadcasting Corporation television and radio services via the satellite.
—Untested anywhere in the world.

—I note the interjection from the learned gentleman that it is an untested system. For the first time in Australia a lead may be given in this country in this area of technology. If he prefers to sit back and wait and have an outdated technology, that is a matter for him, but that is not something this Government will do. The decision was taken in the knowledge that the multiplexed analogue component forms of transmission systems were at the forefront of emerging technology. I am aware of the fact that no MAC system has been employed commercially anywhere in the world. However, on the advice that I have, the form of MAC technology would be employed in future systems of satellite delivered television because of the clear advantages that the technology has over conventional systems.

ANSWER.PARA: In order that honourable members opposite and particularly the honourable member who interjected earlier can understand it, on the advice received, the B-MAC variant, as the transmission standard for ABC television, has considerable advantages. Some of those are its ability to deliver a very high quality television signal, even under adverse conditions, along with six digital audio channels plus a data channel. It will also allow, as part of the ABC's Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service, the provision of a range of radio services, ABC stereo radio services and two other mono ABC radio services which would not have been available with other systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been conned by the bureaucrats.

—I would rather take advice from bureaucrats in my Department than from the honourable member. There is the capability to offer teletext services, on-screen emergency warnings, educational and other services by the use of the data channel. Further, it is expected that commercial radio and television will follow this lead in Australia and will also employ B-MAC. Furthermore, there are excellent prospects that it will be employed in many other countries. In conclusion, it is worth noting that with B-MAC Australia will have one of the most technologically sophisticated broadcasting systems in the world. The result will be better television and radio facilities for all Australians, something that has been provided by this Government and something which was not, in fact, provided during the term of the previous Government, when the area of communications was in a state of paralysis for four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industry inform the House of the outcome of his recent discussions in the United States of America on the implications of the 1985 farm Bill and particularly its potential impact on Australia's primary producers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I would probably need to make a statement to do justice to the depth of the discussions. The purpose of my visit to the United States in particular and to Canada was to identify Australia's position on the more general questions of trade in agricultural products. It was consistent with the position taken by the Prime Minister, particularly in Brussels and also in the United States leading up to a possible further round of multilateral trade negotiations. Australia is of the view-those on both sides of the House are of the view-that it wants trade to be open, multilateral and without excessive subsidisation, particularly as far as agricultural products are concerned. The Administration's farm Bills are very important Bills for Australia's primary producers. The commodity about which I expressed most concern was wheat. While I was in the United States I saw Secretary Block of the Department of Agriculture, Ambassador Brock of Trade, Mr Wolfowitz of State, as well as a range of congressmen, senators and industry leaders.

ANSWER.PARA: At present the United States has a complicated system of farm support. I will not go through all the details of that. Even with its far greater levels of support than our primary producers have, there is a chronic farm credit situation in the United States at present and to some extent that is confusing the thoughts of people in the Congress on the basic logic of the United States farm Bills. They propose tracking down mechanisms with respect particularly to the loan rate, the target price and the deficiency payment system therein. It would be in Australia's interests, by and large, if the United States pursued the Administration's package of Bills. However, the Congress has to examine those Bills. In the first instance it is quite obvious that, no matter how firm the Administration is with respect to its policies-particular people in the Administration such as Mr Regan and Mr Stockman-the Senate in particular in the United States Congress will debate those Bills at great length. Proposals have been put forward by Senator Helms, who chairs the powerful agricultural committee. It is pretty obvious that many other Bills will be put up. For example, we are sure that one will come from Senator Boschwitz and another one from Senator Zorinsky. There will be a lot of discussion.

The position which we particularly wished to identify was that the worst situation from Australia's point of view would be if the loan rate were dropped, thereby effectively dropping the price of wheat on the world markets. At the same time, a compromise-

TALK.START.PARA: —Make a statement. This is disgraceful.

—I ask the Prime Minister: In view of some isolated claims that the economic recovery is stalling, can he assure the House that the Government will achieve the goal set before the 1983 election of achieving 500,000 new jobs in its first three years of office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Newcastle for his question. I can say that not only are we still committed to the goal of achieving 500,000 new jobs in our first three years of office but also the prospects of achieving that target are excellent. I remind all members of the House of the cynicism, the scepticism and the anti-Australianism of the Opposition when we said that. I know it is part of the diet of members of the Opposition which they do not like, but let me feed them some facts. So far this financial year 110,000 new jobs have been created. In our term of office since the Summit of April 1983 a total of 360,000 new jobs have been created. So you can see, Mr Speaker, that we are very much ahead of our target. Of course, that increase in the number of jobs has been associated with a significant fall in the level of unemployment-from over 10 per cent when we came to office to 8.3 per cent now. Very importantly, as all people on this side of the House, who are really concerned with the problem of unemployment, will particularly applaud, there has been a drop of four percentage points in the level of youth unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very instructive, I would suggest, to compare the creation of those 360,000 new jobs under this Government with the record of honourable members opposite when they were in office. May I rhetorically ask the question: How many new jobs does one think they created in over seven years in office? The answer is 340,000. In other words, in less than two years in office we have created 360,000 new jobs and in over seven years their miserable performance was 340,000. Honourable members opposite attempted to justify their economic policies by saying that what they were about was fighting inflation first. It was through fighting inflation first that they were going to create jobs. Were they not great performers in the area of inflation! When they left office the level of inflation was over 11 per cent. This Government has halved the rate of inflation. It is down to 5 per cent from what it was under them. It was double the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development rate and we have brought it down to the OECD rate. That indicates the performance of these self-styled economic managers.

Finally, if we are talking about failures in the area of economic management, I must comment on the performance of their colleagues in Queensland, because one simply cannot talk about economic failures in this country without talking about Queensland. The statistics that I am relying on to show the great performance of this Australian Government show that Queensland has easily the highest level of unemployment of any of the States of Australia. In other words, at 11.3 per cent it is a clear two percentage points above the Australian average. Queensland is the only State that has had a fall in the level of employment over the past year. That is an indication of the performance of the Queensland Government. It just goes to show that it is about time the Government of Queensland faced up to the task of proper economic management instead of going in for all the grandstanding that it is engaging in at the moment. It is becoming easier and easier to understand that the Queensland Government is engaging in massive counterproductive industrial confrontationism to divert attention from the indisputable and increasingly recognised fact that Queensland is easily the worst managed State in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government sees an enormously important role for the Procedure Committee which has just been established. Obviously, some back bench members will see the rights of individual parliamentarians being preserved and enhanced by the establishment of the Procedure Committee. Of course, that will be uppermost in the minds of the people who will serve on the Procedure Committee, all of whom will be back benchers. ANSWER.PARA: Hopefully, in looking at the Standing Orders and the other procedures and functions of the Parliament, the Procedure Committee will also take into account the fact that the Executive of the Government has an enormously important task to perform in the conduct of government in this country and will understand the Executive's work load in carrying out the business of government.

The Committee may also take the opportunity to look again at the legislation committees which have been experimented with in this House previously and not continued. It may well be that we can facilitate the business of this chamber by the establishment of legislation committees running parallel with meetings of the Committee of the Whole. The Committee could also look at the handling of committee reports. It could look at the calling of quorums, which has caused both this Government and previous governments some serious embarrassment-not embarrassment in terms of having to turn up with the numbers but in terms of the business which is being carried out not only by members of the back bench but also by members of both front benches at the time a quorum is called. I do not know that it is altogether a good thing. —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer to the honourable gentleman's claim made recently that the pre-election commitments of the Prime Minister and him that interest rates would fall in 1985-which produced the sort of headlines I have here-related to the post-tax rundown period in 1985. If not, what prediction is he now making?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting question from the high interest rates specialist who has the dubious honour of being, I think, the only Treasurer in this country to preside over 20 per cent plus interest rates. I might add that he has been saying now for weeks that the Government's monetary policy is too lax. He has been running around the financial markets spreading his particular brand of poison, saying that I invite him to believe that the authorities continue to maintain a firm monetary policy. Yet in the same breath he acknowledges that the monetary aggregate cannot provide a reliable guide to current conditions. He says that if monetary policy is being kept firm one is entitled to ask: Where is the evidence?

ANSWER.PARA: On the one hand he is saying that this Government is too soft on inflation. It has got inflation down to only 5 per cent. He says that what we really need is a tight monetary policy. He thinks we need to be as pure as the driven snow in respect of monetary policy. On the one hand he is saying that we need to tighten the money supply and push up interest rates; on the other hand he is saying that interest rates are too high and rising, as though this is some sort of an atrocity. He is saying that we have a lax monetary policy and he is extolling to us the virtues of a tight one.

Let us get this on the record. At the moment the money supply is running at 3 per cent over the top of the Government's target range announced last year at the time of the Budget. The Government suspended the monetary target because of the changed relationship between the monetary aggregates and gross domestic product because of the reintermediation and intermediation taking place in the banking system owing to the Government's policies in respect of deregulation. I might add that they are policies which the former Treasurer always wanted to implement, as he always wanted to implement everything.

The former Treasurer is suggesting, and has been for weeks, that we should chase the 13 per cent monetary growth down to 10 per cent. That means taking about $2,200m out of the system between now and June. One can just imagine what kind of credit squeeze Australia would have and what kinds of interest rates we would have to live with if we tried to take $2,200m more out of the tax rundown. Why is the tax rundown tight? It is tight for two reasons: The first is the financing of the tax payments on the enormous pickup of profitability of Australian business occurring as a result of this Government's policies. The other reason is the float of the dollar, which again the former Treasurer wanted to do but never had the guts, the courage or the strength to push through his Cabinet. Because of the float there is no longer reliance upon capital inflow to satisfy tax requirements. Hence there is seasonal pressure on interest rates at this time of the year. No one has ever denied that. I made that clear when I said in the election campaign that I accepted the view of most market commentators that a further interest rate step fall is ahead of us when we get through the tax rundown period. The honourable member asked me about that a week ago. I have nothing further to add to the answer I gave him a week ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the actions of the Northern Territory Government last year to acquire compulsorily two casinos and the guarantees given by the Northern Territory Government that no taxpayers' money was involved in the purchase. TALK.START.PARA: —The former Northern Territory Chief Minister, one of the former champions of Australian business, and now the honourable member for the Northern Territory, gave all sorts of guarantees in the course of what is probably one of the most infamous episodes in the history of Australian public administration. —The honourable member may squirm.

—Many people abroad fail to distinguish between the States and Territories of Australia. The question is put generally about Australia's reputation. Of course, the honourable member for Grayndler sought an answer in respect of the guarantees. The guarantees given on numerous occasions by the former Chief Minister were that no taxpayers' money was involved, that Territorians would not be contributing one cent for the purchase of the casinos. That is not the case. We have found that the Northern Territory Government has lent $21m to the new owners to part finance the acquisition and given a further guarantee of $26m in loans raised through a Sydney bank. On top of that, the gaming tax of 20 per cent, which was paid by Federal Hotels, has been dropped to 8 per cent for the new owners. ANSWER.PARA: What was the basis for this confiscation, this unprecedented piece of vandalism, on the part of the honourable member for the Northern Territory? He could see the dream of a $300m casino complex in Darwin. But his successor, Mr Tuxworth, a week or two ago said that the concept in the cold light of day did not make much sense. In other words, the world had been promised and the issue had fallen apart. In particular, the current Chief Minister and his members have given themselves extraordinarily high salary increases in recent times. I think from memory that the Chief Minister is paid more than the Prime Minister, and members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly are paid more than members of the House of Representatives.

In conclusion, we have seen an outrageous episode, as I have said, in Australian public administration. The assurances given by the honourable member for the Northern Territory were not worth a bean. Members of the Northern Territory public are carrying the folly of this piece of vandalism on their backs in terms of their contribution to these casinos, and the loss of the gaming tax. This was brought about by the Liberal-National Party Government members, the people who supposedly worry about the sanctity of government business arrangements, the word of governments and the expectations of business in respect of arrangements with governments. If any blame is to be placed for the serious damage that has been done to the outlook for business investment in the Northern Territory it resides in one place-with the current honourable member for the Northern Territory.
