SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am very pleased to be able to speak in support of this legislation, in introducing it, which will provide a statutory basis for the involvement of the Commonwealth in soil conservation. It has long been a belief of mine that the Commonwealth has an important role to play in actively encouraging and co-ordinating the conservation of our land resources. In the long term it is the capacity of these resources to sustain use which will determine the well being of our primary industries. This Bill will allow for the provision of financial assistance for soil conservation projects undertaken by the Commonwealth, by the States, or by individuals and non-government organisations. It also provides for a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee to provide advice to the Minister concerning the allocation of financial assistance and the Commonwealth's role in soil conservation in general.

The problems of land degradation in Australia are extremely severe and costly. There can be no doubting the seriousness of the problem. Our country is not well endowed with land resources, at least not from an agricultural perspective. Our soils are fragile and limited. It is our responsibility to husband these scarce resources in a manner that reflects the fact that they are finite and cannot be taken for granted. Yet the damage is already widespread. Erosion, salinity and tree decline are afflicting over half of all agricultural land and poisoning waterways in this country. Regardless of the historical reasons for the loss of this most vital resource, it is of the utmost importance that the pattern be halted and prevented from recurring in the future. Furthermore, wherever possible, attempts should be made to restore degraded land.

There is already a strong awareness in all sectors of the community that we have reached a critical point in the process. Should land degradation continue at the level experienced in the past, there is no doubt that the longer term economic welfare of this nation will be placed at grave risk. This Government recognises the problem as one of the most important, if not the most important, in the natural resources area and one which is clearly beyond the resources of State governments alone to tackle effectively. The national dimension of the problem calls for an adequate response by the Commonwealth in the interests of the long term welfare of the nation. This Government has a longstanding commitment to safeguard the nation's agricultural resources. Since attaining office we have moved quickly to fulfil this commitment.

In fulfilment of one of its major pre-election agricultural policies, the Government established the national soil conservation program. I would like to take this opportunity briefly to discuss this initiative. The program aims to develop and implement national policies for the rehabilitation and sustainable utilisation of the nation's soil and land resources. In essence, this is being done by enhancing the expertise and administrative authority already available in the States and local governments and by encouraging the efforts of farmers and the general community. The program's philosophy is consistent with that of the national conservation strategy, namely, that Australia should maintain the essential ecological and life-support systems, such as soil regeneration and protection, on which human survival and development depend. As such, the program represents a major practical attempt to achieve objectives set by the national conservation strategy.

The national soil conservation program is not just concerned with providing funding to other bodies to spend on soil conservation. It embodies its own policies and philosophy which seek to provide a national approach to combating land degradation in Australia. It recognises the basic interdependence of soil, water and vegetation and the role each plays in land stability. Land is perceived as a complex entity made up of each of these resources and the interactions between them. It also emphasises a preventative rather than a corrective approach.
The program is based on five major objectives:
(i) That all lands in Australia be used within their capability;
(ii) That land capability assessment and whole catchment/regional land management concepts be used as a basis for land planning;
(iii) that all land users and levels of Government meet their respective responsibilities in achieving soil conservation;
(iv) that effective co-operation and co-ordination occur between all sectors of the community, disciplines and agencies involved in the use and management of land and water resources; and
(v) that the whole community adopt a land conservation ethic.

These objectives provide the national soil conservation program with its direction and act as a guide in project selection. They are not set in concrete and may change as the program develops and progress is made. I am pleased to be able to report that the program has received a high level of support from the public. This support has translated into active co-operation from primary producers, conservation groups, State and local governments, as well as academics and researchers. A major task of the program is to continue to raise the level of public awareness about this often insidious problem of land degradation.

Of course it is in the interests of all Australians that the damage caused by land degradation is minimised. Not only does it undermine productivity but also it results in severe off-site costs that are borne by the public at large. Nowhere is this more dramatically obvious than the lower reaches of the Murray-Darling system where water quality is often very poor as a result of erosion and salinisation occurring throughout the catchment.

The Bill establishes a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee which is constituted as an expert and impartial body charged with several responsibilities. The main function of the Committee will be to provide advice to the Minister on projects to be funded under the national soil conservation program. It will also provide advice on priorities and strategies for activities by the Commonwealth relating to soil conservation. As such, it will allow the Commonwealth to have a co-ordinating function in soil conservation-not in competition with the States but complementing and co-ordinating efforts nationally. This Committee will provide an opportunity for non-government groups such as producer organisations and public interest groups to have an input into how the problem should be tackled by the Commonwealth.

The Department of Primary Industry will, through appropriate processes, publicise the fact that applications may be made for financial assistance for proposed or existing soil conservation projects. The Committee will consider such applications and advise the Minister as to which candidate projects should be funded out of moneys appropriated under the Bill and on areas where soil conservation projects need to be commissioned.

It will also make recommendations as to the terms and conditions that should apply to the agreements under which the assistance should be paid. This selection process would normally take place annually. The Soil Conservation Advisory Committee will also assess the success of projects funded by the Commonwealth and of the workings of the Act itself and will report through the Minister to the Parliament each year.

The total appropriation under the Bill, as I have already stated, is not fixed at any level. While it would be true to say that it would be almost impossible to provide too much support for soil conservation, I would like to make it clear that the Bill is not an attempt to have the Commonwealth shoulder the entire responsibility for soil conservation. This is neither possible nor desirable. The Commonwealth, by establishment of the national soil conservation program and by providing financial assistance under this Bill, is seeking to act as a catalyst to stimulate improved soil conservation by those with more direct responsibility in this area. The Bill provides that separate appropriations be made for the States, for Commonwealth departments and for other persons, such as research or education bodies, tertiary institutions, or private companies or researchers. The relative size of the three appropriations will reflect the general capacity of each sector to contribute to the national soil conservation effort and the probability therefore is that the States will be the major and the Commonwealth the minor recipients, with the other group falling between.

Funds appropriated for use by organisations and individuals will be paid into a trust account to be known as the National Soil Conservation Program Fund. Payments for projects, other than State or Commonwealth projects, will be made from this fund. These projects will be more numerous and usually smaller than State or Commonwealth projects. Experience has shown that in such cases the flexibility offered by a trust account is necessary to ensure efficient use of the Budget allocation. I must admit that it is not absolutely necessary to have a trust account, but that did become the very basis for this piece of legislation. This legislation has been paid the supreme accolade of being fought by Department of Finance officials all the way down the line. I insisted that there be legislation so that future razor gangs and fiscal fiends do not get away with it easily. Individuals and organisations may not always be able to conveniently operate in conformity with the budget cycle while at the same time efficiently managing a project. For example, a project undertaken by an academic institution will usually operate on a calendar year, not on a financial year basis. The fund will also serve as a repository for gifts and bequests where appropriate and for paying the expenses of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee.

The Bill provides that financial assistance be subject to a number of conditions and that each project further be subject to an agreement. The conditions specified in the Bill relate generally to accountability for funds, observance of the agreement, repayment or withholding of funds where there has been misuse or error in the conduct of the project or the handling of funds, provision of records and reports, and the fate of revenue or windfalls derived by the recipient of assistance. In short, the Bill provides for the sort of responsible control that would be expected where government expenditure is being incurred. The agreements between the Commonwealth and those undertaking projects with the use of financial assistance provided under the Bill will be more specific documents which, in addition to containing any of the conditions set out in the Bill, will specify the financial assistance to be provided and describe the purpose and nature of the project in question.

I should like to make it clear that the soil conservation projects that can qualify for financial assistance under the Bill are not limited to actual construction works and field activities. Soil conservation consists of prevention as well as correction, and projects involving education, publications, training, demonstrations and research will all be considered by the Advisory Committee. Indeed, given that conservation is a national issue and that the Commonwealth is able to bring a perspective that is not always available to the States, I expect that the Bill will prove particularly effective in this regard.

It is difficult to provide any quantifiable financial impact of the Bill. The Commonwealth has made $4m available to the national soil conservation program in the current financial year but I have earlier indicated that there is no fixed appropriation under the Bill. Administrative costs within the Department are currently in the order of $180,000 a year, about half of which includes the services of officers seconded from State soil conservation services to assist in the development of the national soil conservation program. When these secondments are terminated in about two years, the cost will therefore be approximately halved. However, with the passage of this Bill, the expenses and allowances of the Advisory Committee-as determined by the Remunerations Tribunal-will have to be met. It is estimated therefore that administrative costs to the Commonwealth will eventually settle at about $120,000 per annum and that this will not vary significantly even if the amount of financial assistance for soil conservation were to be considerably increased, which we all hope for. On the positive side, the benefits of the national soil conservation program are expected to be considerable. It is not possible to predict a likely figure for the savings in terms of future productivity and reduced off-site costs, but they are certain to exceed greatly any outlay by the Commonwealth.

Before concluding this speech, I would like to emphasise the Commonwealth's commitment to soil conservation and the place of this Bill within that overall commitment. Historically, the Commonwealth Government's involvement in soil conservation has been on an in and out basis. The previous Government opted out of soil conservation completely so that at the time the present Government took office there was no involvement at all. This Government turned around that disastrous decision and established the national soil conservation program. The national soil conservation program, as I have explained, has the overall aim of ensuring that the use of our land resources takes places on a sustainable basis. The Bill, limited as it is to the provision of financial assistance, is only a part-albeit a significant part-of the Government's commitment. This significance extends beyond the actual benefit that will accrue from projects undertaken by means of financial assistance provided under the Bill.

The previous Government justified its dilatory attitude to soil conservation on the grounds that because the direct constitutional responsibility for land use rests with the States, the Commonwealth need not become involved. However, it is now obvious that the magnitude of the land degradation problem is such that a national perspective must be obtained with the Federal Government providing a means of co-ordinating this perspective, as well as making its own direct contribution to soil conservation. This Bill is one means or ensuring this. If future governments refuse to commit funds to soil conservation, this can no longer occur by convenient administrative measures; it will require a conscious and public act not to appropriate moneys under the Bill. Any failure by future governments to appropriate funds will be explicitly reflected in the annual report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. The Bill is therefore explicit and enduring evidence of this Government's commitment to the national soil conservation program and to the fight against land degradation. I commend this Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to continue bounty assistance to the industry producing injection-moulding machines for the production of plastic goods and parts for such machines for a further four years. The bounty will be paid at the rate of 20 per cent of value added in the first and second years, reducing to 10 per cent of the value added in the third and fourth years. Since 23 May 1979, local production of the machines and parts therefor has been assisted by a 15 per cent duty and a phasing bounty which was to have expired in May 1984. In January 1983, following representations by the remaining local manufacturers, Johns Consolidated Ltd and Battenfeld (Aust) Pty Ltd, the industry was referred to the Temporary Assistance Authority-the TAA-which concluded that short term assistance was not justified. However, in view of the performance of the local industry, the Government decided that an immediate review of long term assistance arrangements was necessary.

A reference was sent to the Industries Assistance Commission on 30 June 1983 seeking a report on or before 29 February 1984 on what long term assistance arrangements should be provided to the industry. Further, in view of an earlier submission to the TAA by the Department of Defence, in which that Department expressed concern at a situation where Australia's injection-moulding machine manufacturing capacity might disappear, the Commission was asked to provide additional advice on the assistance required should the Government decide to maintain the industry on defence strategic grounds. Pending the completion and consideration of the Commission's report, the Government also decided that short term assistance was required and proposed that temporary assistance by way of an additional bounty be paid to the industry from 10 June 1983 until 22 November 1984.

The Commission presented its report to the Government on 28 February 1984. In its report the IAC commented that the Australian market for injection-moulding machines expanded by 50 per cent between 1979-80 and 1981-82, but in 1982-83 fell back to about the level existing in 1979-80. Local production of injection-moulding machines fell by some 65 per cent in the four years to 1982-83, due mainly to the demise of Johns Consolidated Ltd and to an increase in imports. The Commission further stated that in terms of current dollars, total competitive imports increased by over 100 per cent in 1981-82 relative to the previous two years, and although imports declined in 1982-83, the level was still double that observed in 1979-80. The Commission also stated that there had been considerable changes in the industry since 1979 and that these had resulted in the only remaining local manufacturer, Battenfeld, maintaining market share but with relatively low levels of profitability. The Commission reported that the adjustment difficulties associated with the quite significant reductions in assistance since 1979 had been exacerbated by the difficult economic conditions that characterised the early 1980s. This factor, combined with evidence suggesting that local manufacturers could eventually be competitive with tariff-only assistance and the fact that with assistance of this order local production could be regarded as relatively economically efficient, influenced the Commission to recommend further assistance to facilitate adjustment to the long term rate of 15 per cent.

To minimise the direct cost of assistance to user industries and to facilitate adjustment to the long-term rate, the Commission recommended additional assistance by way of a bounty. The level of bounty assistance requested by Battenfeld was slightly higher than the level recommended by the Commission. However, the Commission considered that assistance at the level recommended would provide Battenfeld with the opportunity to restructure its operations, while at the same time not shield it from the pressure to adjust to the relatively low long term tariff rate. The Commission also concluded that no additional assistance would be necessary to maintain the industry on defence strategic grounds. On 10 October 1984 the Government announced it had accepted the Commission's recommendations that bounty assistance to the industry be continued for four years and that the long term duty rate of 15 per cent continue to apply. This Bill will provide over the next four years a bounty equal to 20 per cent of value added in the first two years and 10 per cent in the third and fourth years, with an upper limit of $0.6m per year for the first two years and $0.4m for the remaining two years. The Bill allows the upper limit to be varied in a particular year to cover unforeseen circumstances provided the total bounty does not exceed $2m over the four-year period.

The Government proposes to monitor closely the performance of Battenfeld to ensure that the intent of the assistance arrangements is achieved and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce will report to the Minister annually in this regard. Finally, the Bill includes a number of provisions in Part III which are designed to update the administrative provisions in the existing Act. These provisions are modelled on a number of provisions in recent bounty Acts.
Financial Impact Statement: The cost of bounty assistance between 10 October 1984 and 9 October 1988 will not exceed $2m. I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on the Sugar Agreement Bill was interrupted, I told the House that the greater number of workers in the sugar industry were members of the Australian Workers Union. I called on that union and other unions whose members inevitably will be affected to put the well-being of their members before any misguided party political subjugation of their duty to members. I now call on those unions to join with the sugar growers and millers in this hour of need to act in concert for the common fight for the common good of their communities. Not to do so now, with great urgency, will be a denial of meaningful representation on behalf of union members. If I am wrong in my assessment indicating a grave situation; if the sugar millers are wrong; if all the indicators and forecasts suggesting things are going to get worse before there is a revival in the sugar industry are wrong; if the growing unemployment statistics in sugar-producing areas are wrong; if, despite all the portents of impending disaster, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) knows better; if the Hawke Government believes the position is not critical, that no threat exists to the economies and infrastructures of the sugar towns and cities along the eastern seaboard from far north Queensland to northern New South, that the internal industry review cannot be undertaken and a restructuring effected for profitability before a collapse in the sugar industry-let the Minister for Primary Industry or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) inform this House by what criteria the Government refuses to act in the interests of all people dependent on the sugar industry. To say that government action will depend on the conclusions reached by the internal review of the sugar industry is not satisfactory when it is clear that a contingency government plan should be readied in case more urgent action is required should a total collapse become imminent.

SPEECH.PARA: If, under any circumstance, this Government will not be prepared to initiate an emergency support plan, let the Prime Minister so acknowledge it and stop what then must be seen as a pretext of concern engendering misplaced trust in an uncaring and short sighted government. Any support given to the sugar industry is an investment promising a continuing return to Australia. Mr Fred Soper of the Queensland Cane Growers Council, in his address to the recent conference of that organisation, said:

Sugar exports from the cane growing industry earn $400m to $800m a year for Australia. That we all know. But the flow-on, or multiplier effect, creates jobs throughout the economy in transport, milling, manufacturing, shipping and other service and support industries. If we used the 'three to one' multiplier formula adopted by the National Farmers Federation for determining the total value of an industry, we would see the real value of cane growing somewhere between two and three billion dollars a year.

Like Mr Soper and his growers, we too are asking the Government to help save an industry which is a vital part of the economy, a major creator of employment and a major earner of export income operating competitively in international markets.

Earlier today, the Minister for Primary Industry drew to the attention of this House a matter relating to the proposed United States Farm Bill. One of the main reasons for this Bill being introduced was the European Economic Community's unyielding response to export-dependent industries throughout the world to a request to stop dumping subsidised produce on the world market. Their response has prompted this move by the United States which, in the short term, could further disrupt Australian exports unless the United States action forces a return to sane marketing procedures. The proposed United States Farm Bill, which has been introduced to Congress, has the potential to alter radically world agricultural markets. The Bill plans to deregulate American agriculture and concentrate on a more export-oriented market approach. This proposal holds many repercussions for Australian Primary exports, including sugar.

The Bill has come about because the Americans had become fed up with watching the European Economic Community steal markets from the United States and Third World countries, with the EEC taxpayers subsidising the exported primary produce. The American Administration has given notice that it is prepared to start an all-out trade war with the EEC to counteract its dumping by matching subsidised prices even if world market prices are lower than United States production prices. It will offer attractive credit terms to buying countries and will even accept the soft currency of the Third World countries. With this threat, hopefully, the EEC will show some sanity and will at least impose production quotas. The EEC is subsidising mainly inefficient and uncompetitive producers. In closing, I say to this House and especially to members of the Government that they must act to provide support for the Australian sugar industry before the tragic and irreversible collapse of the communities totally dependent on the production of sugar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a plea to the Government in regard to the greatest crisis in the long history of the Australian sugar industry. I speak in support of what has been said today in this House by so many of my colleagues. We are dealing with a Bill which is pertinent to the pricing of sugar in Australia. The Sugar Agreement Bill addresses the domestic price issue and the important issue of maintenance of control over imports of sugar. The amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), draws attention in a very pertinent way to the crisis to which I referred.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has not been present in the House for most of the debate. It is pleasing to see that he is back here at this juncture. I hope that, in addressing the House at the end of this debate, he will give some indication of the progress being made by his Government in dealing with the very crucial situation facing the Australian sugar industry. The question is: What will the Federal Government do to assist the industry at this time? Historically, assistance for the surgar industry has been provided with a view to cushioning problems and to making it possible for the industry to adjust to international marketing difficulties. At other times provisions have been made to solve some internal difficulties within the Australian sugar growing industry.

The historic success of the efforts of past governments to assist this industry has set a pattern that I believe demonstrates what can be done through effective co-operation on the part of the Federal and State governments and the sugar industry. The efficiency of this industry surpasses that of any other primary industry in Australia and is perhaps a model for primary industries around the world. This is so because there has been an adherence to a free enterprise approach within the industry towards its management. I refer to management of quotas on production, management of mill handling and, in particular, the management by the Queensland Sugar Board across the whole spectrum relating to each year's product, and the proper management and handling for sale of that product, not only domestically but also on the export market. This has occurred as I mentioned earlier, as a consequence of the historical development of a great industry in Australia.

The success of the industry has been, part and parcel, the result of negotiations frequently carried out by the Federal Government of the day on international marketing and international sugar agreements, which tragically do not exist at the moment. Those negotiations have made it possible for the industry to be one of our biggest export contributors over so many years. The last major crisis, which approached the proportion of the present crisis but was not so great, occurred in 1964. At that time confidence in the industry had been almost totally lost. There was a pattern of confusion similar to that which exists today regarding how the problem could be solved. There was pessimism of a similar nature in respect of pricing, particularly on the export market, of sugar produced in the 1964-66 triennium. The Federal Government of the day, which was of a different political persuasion to the present Government-I refer to the then Liberal-Country Party Government-put forward constructive propositions. It negotiated with the industry. It looked a the bleak outlook but said: 'Let us not despair. Let us take action'.

At that time the pundits, led by Mr Rex Patterson, who was then a member of this House and whose name was mentioned earlier today, were all for control of the industry and for reducing productivity, acreages and quotas. A report at that time suggested that this ought to be done. I offer a warning to the Minister for Primary Industry. Should he follow that course and listen to the bureaucrats in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and certain bureaucrats in his own Department who are hell bent on reducing the productivity of this country's sugar industry, it will be a disaster for the industry and a disaster for primary industry generally in Australia. We can bet our lives that that kind of contraction-I shudder at words I heard from both sides today suggesting that people should be eased out of the industry-will wreck this industry, and do not want to see that happen.

In 1964 it was good enough for the Government of the day to ensure that funds flowed to the sugar pool to assist producers in the critical year 1964-65. There was pessimism. There were those who said: 'This won't do any good because the price won't rise. We'll face further difficulties at the end of that period and onwards'. I am appalled at the thought that we are so naive that we will merely act upon predictions of a price fall in the immediate year and two years ahead, as has been mentioned in this House today. If we are so pessimistic about this industry, what about all our other industries? One could make similar gloomy predictions about every primary industry. Let us take other industries, such as the manufacturing industries. Let us look at the position of the steel industry only a short time ago. Many economists said that Australia should not have a steel industry. They said that we did not have the equipment, that the industry had run down and needed to look at the reality of the situation, that we could not be competitive with the rest of the world. The largest public company in Australia said no to that philosophy. It came to this Government, the Government that sits on the treasury bench today, and put its case. It frightened the Government into realising that it needed support, and it got it.

I hope that every supporter of the sugar industry in Australia will fight in the same way to get immediate action from this Government that is so reticent at present and from this Minister who made promises in the last election, who has done very little since that time to honour those promises and who has virtually handed over the negotiating to the Prime Minister. I wonder what that is all about. It is the responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industry to be the front runner in this matter. I hope that on 1 April next some reality will be seen in this very vital issue. Let there be no illusions about who the beneficiaries will be. The beneficiaries will be the entire Australian community. This industry is a large industry. If it is not assisted the effect on employment and on many major cities and towns will be devastating.

If we look merely at the requirements for the year ahead we find that there are three essentials. We must ensure that the next crop goes in, that the farmer has the wherewithal to make it possible for his plantings to take place. That means an outlay-in many instances an outlay which is a financial drain that cannot be coped with at present. The financial institutions are concerned, the growers are concerned and the mills are concerned. It is a closely-knit operation. Earlier today a new member of this House, prominent in the Australian Labor Party, criticised what he described as wealthy sugar growers and wealthy mills. What sheer rubbish. It is a shocking indictment of his Party and himself that he could make such a claim. It shows just what poor debate must take place within the ALP on this major issue.

Let us take the second important consideration. Are we to reduce our productivity until there is adjustment on a world basis or are we able to keep pace with supply through the storage of sugar, an option which is unique to this industry? If we have an over-supply of meat, what do we do with it? If we have an over-supply of perishables in so many other primary industries, what do we do with it? In the case of sugar, one can at least carry forward stocks. In the last decade our storage capacity for sugar has been increased and our handling facilities for sugar have been updated. Perhaps there is a need for some rationalisation of mill throughput, but that rationalisation is currently taking place anyway. There is very little need to look to the grower aspect in terms of reducing the availability of opportunities for the sugar producer himself. Whilst some producers in some areas face immediate difficulties, they would be able to survive on a base price of around $240 a tonne which has been mentioned. If there are difficulties in particular regions or zones, they should be within the province of the State governments concerned-the governments of ueensland and New South Wales.

I speak, of course, with particular interest in the industry in New South Wales. Perhaps its production, relative to that of Queensland, represents a small proportion of total Australian production. It is, nevertheless, a very important sector of the entire industry. It is important to a very big region of northern New South Wales. It may be news to some honourable members who were critical in the debate earlier today that all the mills in New South Wales are owned by a growers co-operative. There is no wealthy milling operation in the State of New South Wales. Likewise, most of the producers are small producers. There are no wealthy sugar producers in New South Wales. What we have is a group of growers and sugar workers in this State who are depending on some action by both the Federal and State governments.

Let me make one important point as far as New South Wales is concerned. During the present off-season the sugar mills are closed. A great number of people who normally would be engaged on maintenance within those mills have been stood down for up to three or four months. This has a tremendous impact on the employees and on the immediate communities in which they live. In addition, the growers are skating on what might be described as thin ice in respect of their program of sugar growing for the coming season. They are depending on some action by the Federal Government and by the State Government of New South Wales. A request has been made to the New South Wales Government to assist the sugar milling co-operative. It would be fair and reasonable for that kind of support to come from the New South Wales government.

Similar action has been taken in respect of some co-operatives in Queensland. My colleagues from as far north as the electorate of Kennedy, which is a big sugar-growing area, and others who have been mentioned earlier in this debate, from right down the Queensland coast have an interest in this matter. They have a practical understanding of what has been done by the Queensland Government to assist co-operative mills in Queensland. We acknowledge that that section of the problem is one with which State governments can assist. What State governments are saying, quite correctly, is that the real assistance for the grower must come from the Federal Government.

I put it to the Minister for Primary Industry and to the Government of which he is a member that some action should be taken immediately. There has been a suggestion that it would require an infusion of at least $80m into the sugar pool. If the excuse is that budgetary reasons prevent that being just a generous grant put forward to the industry at this time; there is a very serious alternative that can be considered. That alternative is simply that a loan be made, as occurred in 1964. If the Government wants to be generous, let it carry some of the interest costs. Let it be realistic in that regard.

If finance is allowed to flow into the sugar pools on the basis of what has occurred in the past, the precedent has been set. No doubt the fear being expressed is that next year it will be worse, and the year after it will be worse again. Governments take many risks. Governments of the past have taken many risks. Governments in the future will take many risks. Let us take a risk on the sugar industry and give it some financial assistance at this critical time-not in six months, 12 months or 18 months, and certainly not at the end of the long haul of some review of the industry's structure, because that would be far too late.

The significant requirement is action now because, like any other business, if one lets the finances run down beyond a point of redemption, the task is too big, the damage is too great and the rescue processes are too difficult. In comparison with many other commitments of this Government, it would be a very small and negligible approach financially to assist this industry at this time. I am sure that the confidence that it would be able to generate would not be restricted merely to what would be the consequence for the sugar grower, the co-operative mills and other mills that have financial difficulties. It would be the means of avoiding a further growth in outlay in respect of unemployment benefits and financial commitments that would arise in the communities of the sugar growing areas of Australia. If one applies the most simple of analogies in respect of the economics of it all, the basis of support of this kind is an insurance against something that could be far worse in a very short time if action is not taken.

I make that appeal particularly in respect of my own electorate of Page in northern New South Wales, the electorate of Richmond, whose member spoke earlier today, and, of course, the electorates of my colleagues from the State of Queensland. This industry is too important to be sacrificed at this time by a lethargic government and by a Minister who is prone to listen to bureaucrats and to economists who do not have a practical understanding and who, I fear, may not have the kind of sympathy that in the past has paid off when it has come to support of a major primary industry. I conclude by saying that the challenge is not so great comparative to other challenges which this nation faces at present. What is required is reality on the part of the Minister. I hope that this afternoon he will give some indication of the sympathy on the part of the Government and himself that is long overdue in this important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not able to participate in the debate or listen to it earlier because Cabinet met this morning. The Sugar Agreement Bill is a simple Bill. It is about the domestic price of sugar, the Sugar Agreement and the import embargo. The Government has provided members of the House with an opportunity to discuss this industry and to represent their electorates. The debate has been a lot wider than the Bill itself. The reason why people have been wanting to speak so much on this industry is that the industry is in trouble. It has been in trouble for the past three or four years. The only action taken by the previous Government was to have two reports compiled by the Industries Assistance Commission. It resisted any move at that time to changes the domestic price formula, which would have given the industry more funds. We have taken the opportunity to give a better price formula to the industry so that there is at least some assistance from the domestic price.

SPEECH.PARA: The solutions to this industry are all about politics. They are all about dollars and the best way to spend those dollars, and that is to get a package. One of the big problems is that the difference between the industry now and 20 years ago is the level of export exposure. This industry now sells about 80 per cent of its production on the export market, whereas back in the 1960s it was far less. It is not just for the Commonwealth Government to put money into this industry. The Queensland Government also has a capacity to put money into this industry if it so chooses and it has been meeting some of the needs of the industry. A government that can spend $60m on racecourses also has a capacity to spend money on an industry that is in trouble.

There are many differences between the situation now and 20 years ago. The major problem is in respect of the European Community. The EC grows beet sugar, which is a one year crop. Australia grows cane sugar, which is a three to four year crop. The situation has changed dramatically with the EC. In 1977, when the EC was not a member of the International Sugar Agreement, it was a net importer of sugar. It has now moved to being a net exporter, and its actions and the actions of other countries in expanding production and also the policies of the United States, which has encouraged the development of alternative sweeteners, have fundamentally changed the world sugar market. There is also the health aspect. The development of alternative sweeteners, as well as the capacity of the EC to expand production at any time, is the major problem facing this industry.

I would like to concentrate for a few moments on the EC because the EC has been very assiduous in spreading the story that it was Australia that sabotaged the International Sugar Agreement. I took part in the ISA talks over two years and kept in contact with the Department of Trade officials and the Minister for Trade, the Honourable Lionel Bowen, right through that period. It was not the case that Australia sabotaged those ISA talks because it was only going to be given a reference export availability of 2.6 million tonnes and not 2.688 million tonnes. The whole problem was that the EC had fundamentally corrupted the world sugar market with a massive stock overhang. It wanted a reference export availability of 5.4 million tonnes, which was its record export production. When the Chairman of the ISA talks under the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development placed on the table a chart of reference export availabilities giving the EC 4.9 million tonnes, it was impossible for the EC to go below that figure, not that I think there was any desire of the EC to go below that figure. The talks were sabotaged then.

Australia would have accepted an agreement with economic provisions that would have worked, but the member countries, the countries participating in those talks, could not even agree on reference export availabilities. In other words, we did not have agreement on what the security stock level should be, what the initial stock holding should be and what the price bans would be for stocking and destocking. We did not have any agreement on the basis of criteria for gaining those reference export availabilities in terms of performance. If Australia had accepted 2.6 million tonnes, it would then have been subject to the salami strategy and would have had no provisions in an International Sugar Agreement which would have done anything at all to lift the price. That is the basic reason why Australia was not prepared to go along, once that figure had been put on the table by the Chairman and the EC was no longer in a position to negotiate. As all honourable members know, in dealing with the EC it is impossible to find the decision point. The officials buck pass in terms of the Commission to the member states, and back and forth it goes. It is very difficult to get the EC in a situation where it negotiates in terms that we understand. It only has positions.

The United States is one of our major markets. We now have a quota of 8.3 per cent of the available import market. That has gone down from nearly 5 million tonnes in 1979 to an estimated 2 million tonnes in 1985. Because Pepsi-Cola, Coca-Cola and some of these big users of sugar have now transferred to high fructose corn syrup, and Aspartain as a chemical derivative is available as a sweetener and has passed relevant laws in the United States, there is a long term problem in the developed countries with respect to alternative sweeteners.

In terms of the debate, there were quite a few calls for a bipartisan approach-I welcome that-from members of the Opposition. I welcome the constructive remarks made by some members of the Opposition and I also welcome some of the constructive remarks made by honourable members on my own side. The big problem with a bipartisan approach is that basically we get knocked by the Queensland Government. There is a problem in dealing with the politics of this industry. It is a proud, independent industry. It has four major organisations and is subject to a set of complex regulations and laws and two boards which are controlled by the Queensland Government. Quite frankly, it is an industry which has not been used to dealing with government.

I agree with the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) that there needs to be a tripartite approach on this-that is, the two governments, plus the New South Wales Government and the industry-so that we can get down to working out which way a package of measures should go. Last December the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to the Premier suggesting that there be a joint task force. We hoped that this would be agreeable to the Premier but there have been intimations that Queensland is not really interested in having such a task force of officials. It has now been agreed that a meeting will take place on 1 April. I simply hope that we can get into a working situation with the Queensland Government so that we can develop a package of measures that may meet some of the needs of this industry.

I originally requested such a move in 1984 when I addressed the Queensland cane growers annual conference. I noted that in debate the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) said that I did not attend the other meeting. That was due to the fact that I was overseas. Three days before that meeting I addressed the proprietary millers on the Government's position.

Today there have been calls, again, for across the board assistance. The Commonwealth Government has indicated on many occasions that it is opposed to across the board assistance. It is not just as easy as it was in 1964-65 when some money was given to the industry by way of a loan, which was repaid. We know that the best way to give assistance to this industry, in terms of getting the money back by way of a loan, is to put it into the No. 1 pool. But there is not much sense in giving this industry a loan because the industry has no capacity to repay it. There is not much sense in giving individual growers carry-on finance. The problem which the Commonwealth Government has with across the board assistance is that it is not needs based, that it masks market reality and that it goes to growers and millers alike. Some co-operative millers are in a far different situation from that of proprietary millers. I am not trying to divide and rule by that device, but the assistance does go to growers and millers alike. About 37 per cent of any funds would go to the mills.

It has been estimated that the industry now needs at least $80m a year, possibly expanding if the world sugar situation and market price do not pick up over the next two, three or four years. Even if $80m were pumped in across the board the average producer would receive about $7,000 a year. If it were targeted to growers only, the average grower would receive about $13,000 a year. Certainly that would be an income boost to the growers. The problem with that approach is that all growers have an income problem, but 15 per cent have a really big difficulty with respect to debt. Probably 3 to 5 per cent of growers are in an irretrievable situation. I would suggest that about 80 per cent of the industry is in a bad situation but it is no worse than that which some of the other primary industries in this country have been in through the various cycles. The really big problem coming up for the sugar industry is that of long term contracts and their expiry. That is why, although the industry is conducting a review of its own marketing mechanisms, structures and production details, there is no sense in that going right through into 1987. There is a very big concern in the Government that the industry review is well and good, but if it is going to take until 1987 for the industry to reach some consensus about what can be done to some of its structures I think that will be far too late.

Other parts of the debate have focused on assistance measures. The problem and the challenge is to get a package. As I said, the industry is having difficulty in getting consensus about which way it should go. There have been some moves recently with respect to some of the mechanisms within the industry. We think there are other areas that could be enhanced if the Queensland Government could meet with the Commonwealth and explore those issues. The problem-this gets to the politics of the industry-is that there are different views on different issues because there are different interests between the groups involved in the industry. I believe we need to sort out those issues. As I have said, the Prime Minister has offered Commonwealth assistance in the development of this package. I make it quite clear that the Commonwealth's view is that a package of measures needs to be developed. Quite frankly, there are lots of needs in the industry. There are research needs, the problems of the super-wet belt and farm size in some areas, inadequate irrigation in other areas and a whole range of problems. This whole idea of across the board assistance, to my mind, simply will not meet the needs of this industry. It is not as if the industry is facing a one-year or two-year problem; it is facing a long term problem.

There has been discussion about a sugar summit. The meeting on 1 April is not a summit. I have heard the definition that a summit is any meeting that the Prime Minister attends. But this is a meeting to explore government co-operation so that meaningful assistance can be developed between the governments. It will be a working meeting. It is not as if it will be between, for instance, President Reagan and Premier Chernenko, with all the attendant summitry that goes with that, people with set positions. It will be a working meeting to see what can be done to develop a package of measures such that the Commonwealth is not seen as imposing measures only to get its head kicked in by either the Queensland Government or the industry itself.

A lot of points were canvassed by the Opposition speakers. I do not have time to address them all. A bit of debate focused on who has paid in the most money. I have never really wanted to entertain debate on all of that. When we provided some $22m by way of assistance to the industry, or $20m to Queensland-between the two governments; $10m each-for carry-on assistance, by 30 June last year only $14.74m had been spent. Since 30 June 1984 a further $15.26m has been made available, but from that point on both governments agreed-certainly the Rural Reconstruction Board in Queensland agreed-that debt reconstruction rather than carry-on finance is the more desirable way of helping the industry. Carry-on finance simply means that there is money to be paid back. Debt reconstruction at leasts spreads out the debt. There are some people with massive debt situations whom I do not think any government can assist. So far, other financial agencies have been backing farms which are considered to have long term viability. I have held discussions with the banks, and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia on that matter.

The honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) said that I listen to bureaucrats in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. I do not mind listening to the BAE on some subjects. I think that it would have been a good idea if the sugar industry had been surveyed by the BAE so that we would have figures available on that industry compared with other Australian rural industries. The attitude by Queensland has been to keep the Commonwealth out of this industry. That has been a problem in terms of the Commonwealth, as a government, coming to grips with this industry. Be that as it may, there is nothing to fear from people looking at an industry through some sort of economic microscope. That is not to say that I intend to take any notice necessarily of the BAE, the Industries Assistance Commission or any other government body. It is up to governments to make decisions and not to be told what to do by bureaucrats. I do not know why people fear objective economic examination. The bureaucrats in my Department have no particular position other than that they are pro primary industry and in favour of trying to reach solutions. That is their professional ethic. I could not say the same thing about some of the bureaucrats in other government departments, but that is another story.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory said that I promised some measure of assistance and mentioned the Giru Mill. Again, I would like to nail that claim, not that that will stop members of the Opposition continuing to run the line if they want to do so. Key industry leaders were at a meeting which I anticipated would be attended by suppliers of the Giru Mill. So once more I sat down with them to go through all the problems of the industry. Of course, I welcomed the opportunity to do so at that fully open meeting. I tried to give them a bit of charitable advice in terms of their review and the problems they were having because they were still running with the line that underwriting was the solution to the industry's process problems. I went through all the technical problems of underwriting. Luckily, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), had already said quite accurately in Townsville that underwriting in itself was no absolute panacea for the industry. So I ran through Industries Assistance Commission formulas, Bureau of Agricultural Economics formulas, industry formulas and several formulas which were developed in my Department for underwriting. Those formulas, given the characteristics of this crop, showed that either there would be a massive payout or zilch payouts. In other words, the BAE and the IAC formulations, even in the last three years, would have each paid out on only one year. I told them that there were problems in respect of underwriting. I pointed out that another measure of general assistance used by the Commonwealth is stabilisation but that there is no capacity for the industry to contribute to a stabilisation fund at this stage. I also went through the whole question of subsidisation and the problems of attaching subsidies for reduction or in what form. However, I said to them that one approach could be some minimum reserve price mechanism. I pointed out, of course, that that was not the policy of the Government. However, I wanted them to understand that a formulation could be found that at least provided for an absolute bottom price to the industry and that it was for them to develop that formulation in terms of their own review.

I would have liked to speak about other matters if I had the time to do so. Honourable members have touched on the problems of the mills. It is quite true that the mills have particular problems. I have already said that there is a great difference between, for example, the CSR mills, the co-operative mills and some of the smaller mills. I think it is quite apparent that one of the catalysts for change in this industry will be the mills themselves but I cannot predict when those changes will take place. It is pretty bad to approach the industry on the basis of everyone saying that mill X is the most likely to go. Where there are four or five mills in one regional area it is far better to approach the problem of working out which mill should go in terms of the lines going to the various mills and where the assignments are. That is something which has to be dealt with separately rather than simply by way of across the board assistance.

I thank honourable members for their contributions to this debate. I am not inclined to make heavy political points. I resent some of the distortions that have been made by the Queensland Government on who has been putting in most dollars. I conclude by saying that it is not beyond the capacity of the Queensland Government to help more. I hope we will work together on a package of measures on 1 April.
