SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The principal purpose of this Bill is to give legislative effect in Australia to the Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages signed by Australia in July 1980. The Bill represents a significant step for Australia in that it is the first of the Hague conventions Australia has signed and will be the first to which Australia has given effect.

In addition, the Bill proposes certain other amendments to the Marriage Act 1961 with which I will deal at a later stage. The Bill is, for the most part, substantially the same as that introduced last year.
The Hague Convention

For many years it has been recognised that marriage is such a fundamental and universal human institution that, wherever possible, a marriage celebrated in one country should be recognised as valid all over the world. Nevertheless, there are limits to the extent to which the policy of one country is acceptable in another. To reconcile these conflicting goals a complex set of rules has developed in the common law, governing recognition of marriages involving parties whose domicile is not Australia, or marriages celebrated outside Australia.

In 1983, 35 per cent of all marriages taking place in Australia involved one party who had been born overseas. The common law rules as they now stand would refer the validity of those marriages where one party was still domiciled outside Australia, partly to the law of the domicile.If a marriage takes place overseas it might be necessary to refer to the law of a number of countries to determine its validity in Australia. The Hague Conference on Private International Law in 1976 finalised the Convention on the Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages-the Hague Convention-to facilitate the recognition in one country of marriages solemnised in another country.
Celebration of Marriages

Chapter I of the Hague Convention deals with the celebration of marriages in countries party to the Convention. The Hague Convention requires a member country to allow the celebration of a marriage on its territory where the couple meet the requirements of the law of that country, provided that one of the parties is a citizen of that member country or habitually resides there. At the moment Australian law forbids the marriage of parties in Australia where the law of the domicile of both of the parties forbids it. In practice, it is difficult for celebrants in Australia to form an opinion about the domicile of the parties or the law of a foreign country.

The Bill proposes to deal with this problem by recognising the position which, as a matter of practice, has existed in Australia for many years; namely, that marriage celebrants in Australia marry persons in Australia-whether or not they are foreigners-by reference only to Australian law. To enable Australia to comply with Chapter I of the Hague Convention, the application of Part III of the Marriage Act-dealing with void marriages-is varied by clauses 10 to 13 of the Bill so that the rules of that Part will apply to all marriages solemnised after the amending provisions come into force in Australia or outside Australia under Australian law. This amounts to a variation of Australia's 'choice of law rules' and means that each of the parties to a marriage will only be required to meet the requirements of Australian law before they may marry under that law.
Recognition of the Validity of Marriages

Chapter II of the Hague Convention imposes upon countries that are parties to the Convention an obligation to recognise marriages that are validly celebrated under the law of the place of celebration, subject to certain basic exceptions. This obligation will involve recognition being given to some marriages which would not be considered valid under the common law rules of private international law.

In implementing the Convention the Bill also provides, in new section 88E, that these common law rules will remain in operation to a limited extent, so that even if a marriage would not be recognised as valid under the Convention, it will nevertheless be recognised as valid if the common law rules so provide. Essentially, the Convention operates as a gloss upon the common law, as it will provide an additional basis upon which the recognition of validity of foreign marriages may be afforded.

The Convention rules are contained in a new Part-Part VA-to be inserted in the Act by clause 23. To give the maximum benefit, Part VA is to apply to all marriages whether solemnised before or after the Convention comes into force for Australia. The only difficulty that this may cause will arise where a party to a marriage, which was previously regarded as invalid, has remarried prior to the commencement of the new rules, relying on the invalidity of the prior marriage. Accordingly, there is a saving provision in new sub-section 88D (5) so that the first marriage in that situation will continue to be regarded as void, whether or not it would be valid under the Convention rules. Priority is thus given to the subsequent marriage, which was entered into in good faith.

Part VA will extend recognition to a marriage solemnised in a country outside Australia as valid throughout Australia if the marriage was, at the time it was solemnised, recognised as valid by the law of the country where is was solemnised or, alternatively, if the marriage is recognised as valid under that law at the time its validity falls to be determined-paragraphs 88C (1) (a) and (2) (a). Analogous provisions will apply to marriages solemnised overseas by foreign diplomatic or consular officers.

These rules of recognition will, however, be subject to a number of exceptions permitted by Article 11 of the Convention and set out in sub-sections 88D (2) and (3). A marriage solemnised in a country outside Australia will not be required to be recognised as valid under the Convention rules where: Firstly, either party was, at the time of the marriage, already married to some other person; secondly, either party was not of the minimum Australian marriageable age, which is 16 years for males and 14 years for females; thirdly, the parties were within a prohibited relationship; or, fourthly, the consent of either was not a real consent.

Another provision of Part VA, section 88F, provides, in accordance with the policy expressed in Article 12 of the Hague Convention, that where the question of the validity of a marriage is incidental to the determination of another question-for example, relating to inheritance-the validity question shall be resolved in accordance with the Convention rules. A prima facie method of proof of a marriage alleged to have been solemnised in a foreign country is also provided in section 88G. The Bill also makes a number of other amendments.
Legitimacy of children

Some of these relate to Part VI of the Act, which deals with the legitimacy of children in certain circumstances. One amendment, in clause 26, inserts new sub-section 93 (3) into the Act. The background to this amendment can be found in the recent developments in technology to assist reproduction, most notably the technique of in vitro fertilisation. This technique, together with the related one of artificial insemination by donor, has given rise to discussions in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General with a view to the enactment of uniform State and Territory legislation dealing with the parentage of these children. These discussions have not been concerned with the broader ethical and social issues raised by these techniques; they have simply been directed to the clarification of the status of the increasing number of children born in these ways. In general, the decision has been taken that a donor of genetic material should have no relationship with the child, and the legal parental relationship should be given to the 'social' parents.

In the context of Standing Committee discussions, some doubts were raised as to whether Part VI of the Marriage Act might not unintentionally frustrate part of this uniform law exercise. This would be so if the provisions of Part VI were to be interpreted by the courts as 'covering the field' with respect to the legitimation of children, leaving no room for the State laws concerned to have a valid operation. The problem is a constitutional one to do with the overriding effect of Commonwealth law. This amendment will make clear the intention of the Parliament not to affect the validity or effect of State and Territory laws dealing with the parentage of these children.

The other amendment to Part VI, in clause 25, involves the extension of the operation of section 90 of the Act. That section deals with legitimation by virtue of a foreign marriage, and presently has no operation where the relevant foreign law does not recognise the status of illegitimacy. The amendment will deal with such a case by treating a child as legitimate if its parents subsequently marry. The opportunity has also been taken to amend the application provisions of sections 89 and 90 so that they operate on the domicile of either parent, rather than only that of the child's father. This change reflects the situation in which a married woman now has a separate domicile, since the enactment of the Domicile Act 1982.
Notice of Intended Marriage

Minor amendments are made by clause 16 to section 42 of the Act to improve the operation of the provisions dealing with notices of intended marriage. The most important is the extension, from three months to six months, of the maximum period prior to the date of the marriage within which the notice can be filed. Extension of this time will allow celebrants and parties greater flexibility in making arrangements. The Family Law Council has considered this proposal, which has been put by civil celebrant groups, and sees no objection to it. Australian diplomatic officials are added to the list of those who may witness a notice of intended marriage. This will make the necessary paperwork easier for those who have to come from outside Australia to marry in Australia.
Fees for Civil Celebrants

The Bill inserts provisions to provide that a civil marriage celebrant is not entitled to charge a fee for the solemnisation of a marriage higher than that prescribed by the regulations. This will make it clear that the prescribed fees are the legal maximum that can be demanded for solemnisation. It seems desirable, in light of the particularly vulnerable position of parties about to be married, that there be a clear legislative statement to this effect, for the protection of both parties and celebrants. It is not intended by this provision to affect the ability of celebrants to make reasonable charges for other matters ancillary to the actual solemnisation, such as flowers or music. I should also point out that the Government is keeping under review the level of fees to ensure, consistent with overall economic restraint, that the fees represent an adequate remuneration for this important service. Early last year the fees payable were significantly increased in light of these principles.
Provision of 'Marriage Education'

As a continuing part of the Government's response to recommendation 61 of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act-that 'education for marriage and family life be further supported'-the concept of 'pre-marital education' in part 1A of the Act is broadened to that of 'Marriage Education', by clauses 5 to 9. Organisations working in the area of pre-marital education have often indicated that one of the most useful times to engage in education for marriage is in that period shortly after the marriage has been entered into. Recently this Parliament enacted long needed changes to the laws governing the termination of marriage. This Bill represents another facet of the Government's commitment to resolving the problems faced by ordinary men and women in Australia in that most personal area of their lives. Particularly in extending the grounds for recognition of marriages entered into overseas, in ensuring the legitimacy of children recognised as such by State laws, and in broadening the scope of education for married life, this Bill is an affirmative statement of the importance of marriage as a fundamental and enduring institution. The Bill has no financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have heard the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), at the end of his second reading speech, say that marriage was a fundamental and enduring institution, and the Opposition likewise takes that view. Indeed, the Opposition takes the view, as do most people in the community, that marriage is one of the foundations of our society. Accordingly we believe the Marriage Amendment Bill, which seeks to amend the Marriage Act, is of considerable importance. The Opposition likewise takes the view that the family is the basic unit of our society and that government policy, insofar as this is a role for government policy, should be directed towards supporting the family an buttressing the institution of marriage upon which the family is based. So many of our traditional values are now being brought under challenge and the institution of marriage in particular is being besieged in this way. Accordingly, we believe the Bill should help protect the institution of marriage against those attacks. For that reason, we will in general support it. We will, however, be moving one amendment relating to the fees that may be charged by civil marriage celebrants. I will come to that amendment later.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary purpose of the Bill is to implement the Hague Convention on the Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages, which was signed by the former Government in 1980. The Convention is aimed at alleviating a growing international problem with particular significance to Australia, and that is the recognition by one country of marriages celebrated in another, or between parties domiciled in another country. This is particularly pertinent to Australia-I think the Attorney-General mentioned this statistic-because, as a result of post-war immigration, 35 per cent of all marriages in 1983 involved at least one party who was born outside this country. There is always the danger, usually a remote one, that where a couple who married overseas come to live in Australia or a person who is born overseas marries in Australia, there may be some legal complication concerning the validity in Australia of the marriage, and some question of whether the overseas marriage will be recognised under Australian law.

The common law solution to this problem is complicated and uncertain because it allows the courts to make what is known as a choice of laws. They could, in the right circumstances, adopt either the law of Australia or the law of the foreign country in which the parties celebrated their marriage or were domiciled to determine the validity of the marriage. The shortcomings in this rule are apparent, particularly where polygamous marriages or marriages between persons in a prohibited relationship are involved. For instance, in one country a marriage between close relatives might be recognised but under Australian law such a union would be invalid. The rules by which Australian courts determine which law is to apply are complex and not easily understood by lawyers, let alone laymen. Generations of law students and lawyers have been kept awake at night grappling with these difficult principles and rules of international law. The Hague Convention has adopted a sensible and practical solution to this problem. The outcome of the Convention was, in substance, an acceptance that so far as possible there should be uniform rules throughout the world. Those rules will be, in effect, codified into Australian law by this Bill. The more countries that adhere to and give effect to the Convention, as Australia has, the greater the convenience and the greater the certainty for married persons in Australia and the rest of the world.

If this Bill becomes law the existing choice of law rules will be amended or modified so that, in addition to the common law rules, it will be our law that, with some exceptions to protect against unions that are repugnant to our society, the law of the place where the marriage was entered into will govern the validity of the marriage. If a marriage was validly celebrated under the law of the place of celebration, it will be recognised as valid in Australia. This will mean that in future all questions relating to the validity of marriages entered into in Australia, whether by Australian residents or aliens, will be determined by Australian law. At the same time this Bill will give effect to the Convention by requiring Australian courts to accept as valid any marriage performed in another country which conforms with the laws of that country. There are some exceptions which I believe make good sense and which are recognised in the Convention. For instance, bigamous marriages will not be recognised. These proposals are sound and the Opposition gives them its support.

I turn now to the provisions of the Bill which deal with a unique situation concerning the legitimacy of children. Clause 26 of the Bill deals with State laws affecting children born as a result of artificial insemination or in vitro fertilisation. Those State laws provide different legal consequences for such children, as we learn from an examination of clause 23, depending on what State one looks at. I will have more to say later about those varying legal consequences because it is very curious to look at the differences between the law in one State and the laws in other States.

Clause 23 of the Bill provides that nothing in the relevant part of the Commonwealth Marriage Act affects the validity or effect of any of the State laws. Its purpose is to give some effect to the State laws that are already on the State statute books. This is acceptable as a holding operation. Anything that clarifies the status of children born as a result of artificial insemination or in vitro fertilisation must be desirable. It is for that reason that the Opposition supports this proposed amendment to the law as a holding operation.

The reason for the need to clarify their status, as we have been told by the Attorney-General in his second reading speech, is that some doubts have arisen as to whether Part VI of the Marriage Act might leave no room for the State laws to have a valid operation. The result might be that there would be no law governing the legitimacy of those children or, at least, a very confused situation. Clearly, no one wants that situation to exist. We are told, therefore, that the purpose of this amendment is to make clear the intention of this Parliament to be not to affect the validity or effect of the State laws dealing with the parentage of children born as a result of artificial insemination or in vitro fertilisation. We are therefore in this Parliament legislating to the effect that the State laws remain valid.

There is no doubt that the law should be clear and there is no doubt that to make the law clear we have to declare that the validity of the State laws is not to be compromised or brought into doubt. As I say, the Opposition will support this provision for that reason, and support it as a holding measure. But what a scandalous situation it is that the law on such a subject can differ from State to State. It is obvious from the Bill that in some States a child born as the result of these procedures is treated as the child of the woman concerned, as she is described in the Bill. Under other State law, the child is treated not as the child of the woman concerned, but as the child of the woman and a particular man. Under other State laws the child is treated as the child of a particular man. These discrepancies in the various State laws are, I suggest, quite ludicrous. There is an obvious need for uniform law on this subject so that the status of the children concerned is clear and so that their status does not change from State to State.

We know that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has been discussing the enactment of uniform State laws dealing with the parentage of such children. I put it that it is a disgrace that it has not been able to come to some conclusion about it and have that conclusion implemented. I know that discussions have proceeded. I understand that some of the State laws have been enacted pursuant to that attempt to achieve uniformity. But the fact remains that there is not uniformity and there should be. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General should act, we believe, far more promptly than it has done so far, if that is not asking too much, and it should take steps to have uniform legislation implemented as soon as possible. It is quite unconscionable to have the law relating to innocent children left in a state of such uncertainty any longer. The Commonwealth and State Attorneys-General will be failing in their duty if they do not bring this ridiculous state of affairs to an end, and do so promptly. So we will support this measure as a holding operation, but will have plenty to say if the situation is not soon rectified on a permanent basis.

I should say before leaving the subject that I have another concern about this particular part of the Bill. We are not, of course, as is apparent, legislating on the propriety of the medical procedures which give rise to this problem; nor are we passing judgment on those procedures. But the danger is that we are writing in some form of recognition of the procedures which will no doubt be pointed to by some in the future as some sort of implied approval of them. We are doing that without any real debate on the issue, without having any opportunity to have a real debate on the substance of the issue and without any discussion or declaration in the legislation about the limits, if any, which should be imposed on those procedures and the consequence of those procedures. That, I believe, is unwise. It is unwise because the legislation that we are discussing today will no doubt be pointed to in the future as some sort of precedent. It reinforces-if anything else were needed to reinforce it-just how much of a holding operation this amendment to the law is.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I will give just one example, without taking too much time about it. One of the provisions in the State law is to the effect that a State law may-and I paraphrase the Bill-require a child born to a woman, as a result of the carrying-out of one of these medical procedures in relation to the woman, to be treated as the child of a particular man. One would have thought, looking at it on the surface, that that is not a situation which we could allow to be regarded as a uniform recognition in the law throughout Australia. If there is one State which has, as it apparently does, a provision in its law to that effect, two things follow: Firstly, we should certainly have a national debate as to whether that is what this country wants; and, secondly, it simply reinforces the need to have a uniform situation throughout Australia. I hope that nobody in the future will point to this debate as having given any imprimatur to any of the particular procedures or as to the legal consequences of any of those procedures having taken place. But I regret to say that I have very little doubt that it will be pointed to. I think it is unfortunate that any sort of implied approval of the procedures, or the legal limits following from the procedures, should be given as a result of passing this legislation.

I turn now-again, comparatively briefly-to the question of marriage celebrants' fees which is the subject of the Opposition's amendments which I think has now been circulated. The Bill inserts into the Marriage Act a provision to the effect that a civil marriage celebrant is not entitled to charge a fee for solemnising a marriage which is higher than the fee prescribed by regulation. The fees, of course have been increased from time to time. But questions have arisen as to whether civil marriage celebrants can charge a higher fee than the one that the Government thinks is good for a civil marriage celebrant to charge. The proposal in the Bill makes it clear that they will not be able to charge a fee higher than the one which is set out on the table from the Government. The Opposition takes the view that that is not a proper provision to have in the Act. Indeed, it is a provision that should not be contained in any statutes unless there is an overwhelming case made out for it to be there. I think that many members would agree that to include government price fixing in any arrangement between free citizens should not be undertaken or should not be embarked upon unless there are overwhelming circumstances and an overwhelmingly strong case is made out for that situation to be implemented into law. The Opposition believes that the ordinary principles of contract-or, if one likes to put it this way, the ordinary principles applying when ordinary free human beings come together and deal the one with the other-should be allowed to apply in this case in relation to these matters. People should be free to make whatever arrangements they wish in regard to this matter.

The Government proposal amounts fairly and squarely not only to price fixing by the Government but price fixing in an area that should be a matter for the personal relationship of the individuals concerned and for the individuals to make up their own minds about. That is the reason why the Opposition opposes this provision in the Bill. Clearly, fees should be prescribed because the parties may wish to enter into a contractual relationship on the basis of those fees and therefore they should have some guide as to what the fees will be. However, they may not address themselves to that issue; so in the absence of a specific agreement for the fee to be charged it can be said that the celebrant has a right to charge the prescribed fee.

One could say that probably there should be no argument against that. In principle there is no reason why, when the parties specifically set their mind to the question and bargain that the celebrant can charge a higher fee, he or she should be prevented from obtaining that fee. In fact there is a stronger case for the simple reason that no case was made by the Attorney-General in the second reading speech as to why there should be government price fixing and compulsory adherence to government fees in this area essentially concerning personal relationships. There is no case and, indeed, no attempt being made by the Government to explain why this should be so.

Therefore, the Opposition amendment will delete the Government provision and will insert a new provision to ensure that nothing in the Act may be interpreted as preventing a civil marriage celebrant from charging a higher fee and preventing parties to a marriage from paying that fee if they wish to. It will not be compulsory, but people may wish to pay. No reason has been given in this Parliament as to why the parties should not be free to do that if they wish. There are quite enough government controls on what free citizens do in this country without having any more. If there are to be more restrictions an overwhelming case must be made out as to why citizens' liberties should be restricted in this way.

I will turn finally to the part of the Bill relating to marriage education. The second reading speech is almost silent on explaining changes proposed to be made to the Act in this regard also. However, despite that almost complete state of silence on this issue it appears that in future grants of money will be made to approved organisations engaged in marriage counselling rather than to pre-marriage counselling and that voluntary organisations will be approved if they engage in marriage counselling, not only pre-marriage counselling. Therefore, the Bill seeks to implement a widening of the concept of marriage education. Marriage counselling bodies in Australia perform a very valuable service and it is desirable that they should be recognised by this amendment to the Act. Although the Government apparently is not prepared to use that as a reason for the amendment, the Opposition is prepared to rely on the valuable service provided by these organisations as a justification and as a good reason for widening the provisions in the Act relating to counselling. We certainly do that with a great deal of enthusiasm.

In addition I endorse the call made in the Senate by Senator Durack for more resources to be made available for marriage counselling and marriage education. Senator Durack pointed out in this context that marriage counselling organisations have had a very good success rate. There is considerable evidence to show that they are very successful and therefore should be given every encouragement to continue with their work.

Another matter that arises in this area concerns the establishment by the Government last year of so-called pilot family law centres. It has never really been made clear by the Government exactly what its intention is in respect of these centres. If the proposal for pilot family law centres is to undermine or contradict the work of the voluntary organisations engaging in family law counselling and marriage counselling we will oppose that attempt-if that is what it is-to undermine their activities. Our problem is that at the moment we just do not know what their true role is. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will find it very edifying to read the record of the Senate Estimates Committee debate last year when Senator Gareth Evans was trying not to explain the Government's intention in respect of these family law centres.

Anyone who has read Senator Durack's penetrating cross-examination of Senator Gareth Evans on that occasion in the Senate Estimates Committee hearings would conclude that it was like drawing teeth to get anything out of Senator Evans concerning the Government's exact intentions. Although his officials who were present on that occasion were quite prepared to assist in enlightening senators as to the objective of the family law pilot centres Senator Evans was clearly very reluctant to tell the people's representatives just what the Government's intention was. Therefore, at this stage our complaint is not so much that these centres are undesirable but simply that their role has never been made clear. I say to the present Attorney-General that he is more clear in his language than was his predecessor. I hope he will take this opportunity to tell us exactly the Government's intention in respect of these proposed centres.

It is our view that the Government should tell us about another important matter, counselling services in the Family Court. Those counsellors actually working in the Family Court structure perform a tremendously valuable service and work under enormous hardships. They do not have the resources they need and there are not the numbers of counsellors necessary. As a result there is an increasing waiting list for counselling services to be provided to people who are often in very distressing circumstances. That continuing, mounting and lengthening waiting list simply cannot be allowed to have even more cases added to it without more family law counsellors being made available to resolve those very pressing problems. Most people who work in this field know that the appointment of more Family Court judges is not the complete solution to the problems of the Family Court, rather that many of the problems will be more expeditiously resolved by the appointment of more counsellors because counsellors do such valuable work in unlocking so many of the disputes in which the parties really are at loggerheads.

I urge the Attorney-General on this occasion to give every support to the Family Court counselling services. I give him every opportunity and every encouragement to tell us how the reviews of that service now under way are coming along. Are the reviews on target? Has the review of the Family Court counsellors enough resources? Are there any problems they are having difficulty in resolving? When can we expect some answers from that review? The reviews are looking at some of the industrial relations problems, if I can use that expression in its broad sense, and are looking at the management structure in relation to whether the Family Court counselling service is structured in the right way to provide the right sorts of services necessary.

The Parliament is entitled to know about the progress of these reviews. It is entitled to know when we will get some answers from the reviews and, above all, what the Government is doing by way of appointing extra Family Court counsellors to alleviate the pressing log-jam of cases presently requiring urgent attention, even as a holding measure before the reports from the review bodies are brought down.

Finally, I say that Senator Durack made a plea in the Senate for an inquiry by a Senate committee to look into some of the aspects of the counselling services. I endorse that suggestion. It need not necessarily involve a Senate committee; it could be a House of Representatives or joint committee. In the Parliament we should be looking at questions relating to things such as the pilot family law centres that I mentioned earlier in my remarks. We should be looking at the proper role of Family Court counsellors and the extent to which they should counsel for reconciliation. We should look at whether the Family Court counsellors should be part of the Family Court structure or in some separate and parallel organisation. We should be looking at the relationship of Family Court counselling to marriage counselling services and the cost benefits of counselling. Those matters should be examined by members of this Parliament. I shall take up no more time on that matter, but simply say that I endorse the call made by Senator Durack for those matters to be looked at by a Senate Committee, or perhaps by a joint committee or a committee of the House of Representatives. Such problems go to the root of many of the difficulties faced by individual citizens. We shall do those people a great service if we can help to solve some of their personal problems by providing the proper structure within which they can be solved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to support the Marriage Amendment Bill 1985. I shall confine my comments to several aspects of the Bill that I regard as important and leave my colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) to deal with other aspects of it. I take up a couple of points made by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). I support his call for uniform legislation between States as to the definition of 'child'. It is ludicrous that such problems should arise, and if we can get over the States' rights argument and bring common sense to bear on the matter, I think that we can get around those problems. I do not support the amendment relating to marriage celebrants which seeks deregulation by not requiring the Government to set a maximum fee to protect both the marriage celebrant and the people being married. The honourable member for Menzies may have forgotten that legal aid lawyers are paid a fee set by the Government, and that the lawyers appear to be happy with that arrangement. The position becomes complex when one considers fees for lawyers and doctors. However, it is my impression that the Government will not accept that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary purpose of the Bill, as has been stated, is to amend the Marriage Act 1961 to facilitate the recognition in Australia of overseas marriages. It is fitting that of all countries Australia should put forward this Bill, as Australia has been settled by a large number of people from all over the world. One sees from the latest available statistics that at 30 June 1981 persons born outside Australia made up 21 per cent of the population and, as the honourable member for Menzies pointed out, in 1983 35 per cent of marriages in Australia were entered into by people from overseas. Therefore, the Bill is sound to the extent that it brings some rationality to the laws of marriage where there may be conflicts within the courts.

The second aspect of the Bill with which I deal relates to clauses 5 to 9 which extend to provisions for financial assistance for pre-marital education to marriage education. This arises out of the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act that 'education for marriage and family life be further supported'. The concept of pre-marital education in Part 1A of the Act is broadened to that of 'marriage education' by clauses 5 to 9. Organisations working in the area of pre-marital education have often indicated that one of the most useful times to engage in education for marriage is in the period shortly after the marriage has been entered into. As the honourable member for Menzies said, last year the Government conducted an advertising campaign to halt marriage breakdowns. There are many reasons for such a campaign, and I shall touch on a number of them. The first argument relates to the numbers of people involved. Statistics from the Department of Social Security on the recipients of the supporting parents benefits show that there are 79,000 separated wives, 18,000 separated de facto wives and 4,100 separated husbands. Those figures relate to people who are currently receiving the supporting parents benefits. If one also includes recipients of the widow's pension, it can be seen that the number of divorcees in this category is 52,000 and the number of deserted wives 41,000. The estimated costs in monetary terms for that year are between $1,000m and $1,200m-a substantial amount of revenue from the public purse.

That is not the whole story. We should be more concerned with the social costs-matters such as loss of productivity and high rate of staff turnover. One has only to look at the effect on the work patterns of marriage breakups. I refer to expensive child welfare, increasing pressure from single parents for low cost housing, and many other manifestations of marriage breakups, which are very important. The saddest effect of marriage breakdowns is felt by the children of the marriage. From the time a breakup occurs or a wife is deserted, the children involved are behind for the rest of their lives. They are not brought up in a normal family environment and the social costs cannot be measured. I refer to a report in the West Australian on 13 October 1984 entitled 'Saving Marriages on a Government Shoestring'. The Marriage Guidance Council, the Anglican Health and Welfare Service and the Catholic Centrecare Agency see thousands of people each year. According to Mr Crawley, the Director of the West Australian Marriage Guidance Council, at least 60 per cent of the 1,700 couples seen by the Council last year claim that they were better able to cope with problems and felt happier in relationships after counselling. Mr Crawley said:
If 57-or 3.4 per cent-of those couples could resolve their differences and did not require supporting parents' benefits, the service would recoup all its Commonwealth grant money each year.

That was the practical experience of Mr Crawley, who is engaged in marriage counselling. He seems to think that such counselling is well worth while and I support the call by the honourable member for Menzies that more funds be made available. I hope that in the years to come that an increase in funds will be made.

I refer to clause 15 of the Bill which relates to the addition of a provision to ensure that a civil marriage celebrant is not entitled to charge more than the fees prescribed. I have already touched on that matter and indicated that I do not think the Government will support the amendment by the honourable member for Menzies. It is my experience as a member of parliament that marriage celebrants fill a very worthwhile gap in the marriage spectrum. I wish to mention three celebrants in my electorate, the Mayor of the City of Canning, Mr Ellco Tucoma, the Deputy Mayor of the City, Mr Joe Delle Donne-I am pleased to say that I was able to help those gentlemen to become marriage celebrants-and also Councillor Elorie Griffin. Councillor Griffin is a marriage celebrant of long standing and has conducted many weddings in the electorate of Canning. Civil celebrants fill a gap in the system, and I believe that many people are very much happier to go along to a celebrant rather than to have a wedding service conducted in the church.

The last point I mention, which has already been referred to is clause 26. The clause inserts a provision to make it clear that the provisions of the Act as to legitimation by subsequent marriage do not affect the operation of State and Territory law relating to the legitimacy of children born as a consequence of in vitro fertilisation or artificial insemination procedures. Clause 26 gives the Bill a contemporary flavour. Many of the matters with which the Bill deals have been perfected only in the last couple of years. Indeed, today's Press contains a story relating to a company called IVF Australia, which has been established to market IVF technology and to send Melbourne-trained experts to clinics throughout the world. Australia leads the world in this technology and it will now be marketed overseas. It is clear to anybody who studies this subject that the IVF program will produce many more children in the future for those who cannot have children by normal means. I am pleased to see the Bill taking account of that aspect. I commend the Bill to the House and hope for its speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purposes of the Marriage Amendment Bill have been outlined both by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). I do not wish to traverse what they have said. I think all of us are in favour of uniform rules relating to the recognition of marriages, and I hope that more than the five countries which I understand have presently acceded to the Hague Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages will soon become party to that Convention. A convention of five countries is very much less useful than a convention of 25 or 30 countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also deals with the question of legitimacy of children born as a result of certain medical procedures. The honourable member for Menzies has touched on the import of that matter, and I wish to come back to it later. There are, in fact, three areas that I wish to address: First of all, the fixing of fees for celebrants, secondly, the Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, not a matter which has been addressed in the Bill; and, thirdly, the profound moral and ethical questions raised by scientific developments in biomedical techniques of artificial conception. Let me first of all deal with the question of fees. The Attorney-General has said to us:

It seems desirable, in light of the particularly vulnerable position of parties about to be married, that there be a clear legislative statement to this effect, for the protection of both parties and celebrants. It is not intended by this provision to affect the ability of celebrants to make reasonable charges for other matters ancillary to the actual solemnisation, such as flowers or music.

Flowers are all right, music is okay-one can charge what one thinks the market fairly would bear. But when it comes to fees, that is a different matter. The pavlovian reaction of those whose minds are encased in nineteenth century ideology causes them immediately to say: 'If it's a fee and if we can fix it, we're going to fix it. Mark you, if it's a fee which has anything to do with a union we're not going to fix it. We're going to index it, we're going to give it superannuation benefits and we're going to give it productivity gains'. But a marriage celebrant falls into a quite different class. It does not matter whether a celebrant is drunk or sober. It does not matter whether he is shaven or unshaven, or whether a woman celebrant presents well or presents badly. It does not matter whether she or he is sympathetic, understanding, kind and genuinely interested in what is going on or whether he or she-my God, how we get into this he or she terminology!-is not sympathetic, understanding or anything else but is simply out to make a quick buck. None of these things are to be taken into consideration. A celebrant is to be paid $20 regardless-no more and no less, certainly no more. Of course, that is the purest of nonsense. The reasons why this rather absurd provision has been introduced are given away in the next paragraph of the Attorney-General's second reading speech, where he says:

I should also point out that the Government is keeping under review the level of fees to ensure, consistent with overall economic restraint, that the fees represent an adequate remuneration for this important service.

In fact, what the Attorney-General is talking about is the Government's precious wage accord. Those vulnerable people who, having made the major decision to get married, are apparently quite competent to decide what they should pay for music and for flowers but are quite incompetent to decide what they should pay a celebrant for uttering those words which have for many a beneficial and kindly import and which will have for others a somewhat more lethal import or, indeed, more lethal consequences somewhere further down the track. When one considers that many of the people who are getting married are not only quite competent to make decisions about their lives because, after all, they have already made a very important one but also in the exuberance of a triumph of optimism over experience, are entering into an engagement for a second or third time, one can only wonder why it is necessary to protect them in that one area. Unquestionably there is no basis for such protection. The only basis put forward to support this proposal is perfectly specious.

Let me move on to a quite different matter. The Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was concluded in The Hague in October 1980. It came into force on 1 December 1983 and was signed by Canada, France and Portugal. Switzerland has since become a party to it. The purpose of the Convention may be found in Article I, which states:
The objects of the present Convention are-
a to secure the prompt return of children wrongfully removed to or retained in any Contracting State; and
b to ensure that rights of custody and of access under the law of one Contracting State are effectively respected in the other Contracting States.

In short, this provision seeks to overcome the jungle in which one parent finds himself when a child is abducted by the other parent. The immense and continuing anguish, the sense of isolation and helplessness of parents who find themselves in that kind of situation, are acute. I have seen the problem professionally and I have seen it as a member of parliament. I will look at some of the problems that parents face. First of all, how does a parent track a child down? Secondly, once a child has been tracked down what does a parent do? Does the parent go to the courts of the country in which the child and the husband or wife who has taken that child away are found, while engaged in litigation and worry about whether the child will be abducted again and face the endless delays that courts can pose and the enormous expenses of travel and living and that the lawyers will exact of that parent? Should that parent seek to take the opportunity to snatch the child back? These are very real problems which some parents have to face.

We face here a provision which was concluded in October 1980, for which provision was made in the Family Law Amendment Act 1983-that is, provision for Australia to become a party-and which is still under examination. The delay is inordinate and inexcusable. It passes understanding how time can be wasted and this Convention can be not being given effect to. I ask the Attorney-General to see whether he can speed up the consideration being given to this Convention so that parents who face this kind of appalling situation can be given some aid and comfort by way of a more uniform and workable system in place of the present system which they have to face when seeking to recover an abducted child.

I now pass to a different subject. Developments in biomedical techniques of conception have passed the frontiers of traditional ethical responses and have confronted us with new dimensions in ethical and moral values and questions. Artificial conception, as honourable members will be aware, is dealt with in clause 26 of the Bill, which recognises State laws but which poses some of the problems that were outlined by the honourable member for Menzies. Artificial conception can be achieved through two main methods. First of all, there is artificial insemination of sperm, for example, from a husband to his wife. The second method is in vitro fertilisation, in which case the egg is fertilised in a laboratory and is then implanted, the second part of the process being called an embryo transplant. This is a quite historic and unique development in that the egg is fertilised outside the human body. This first took place in England in 1978.

The problems posed can be seen in terms of surrogacy. Surrogacy can be achieved, first of all, through artificial insemination and, secondly, through a surrogate mother being implanted with an in vitro fertilised egg. Thirdly, there is a technique called NID. The word 'nid' means a nest in French, and that does not seem inappropriate because the acronym NID stands for natural insemination donor. In that case the male, with or without payment, naturally inseminates another women with his wife's consent, under an arrangement which is to ensure that the offspring will be the child of the impregnating male and his wife. This has already happened in New South Wales.

The new medical realities that we face illustrate the dimension of the moral questions that we must confront. I would like to pose some of those questions in terms of an examination of three different cases or sets of facts. Let us take first of all surrogate motherhood. Should commercial surrogacy be allowed? What of non-commercial surrogacy? The concern for this important issue is felt everywhere. Every State of Australia is having or has had inquiries into artificial forms of conception. National guidelines were laid down on in vitro fertilisation in 1982 by the Medical Research Ethics Committee, a committee operating under the Department of Health. Incidentally, these guidelines were a world first.

In New South Wales at present all aspects of artificial conception, including surrogacy, are under examination by the New South Wales Law Reform Commission under the direction of Mr Russell Scott, the Deputy Chairman. The Warnock Committee in England, which reported in July 1984, recommended that commercial surrogacy should be a criminal offence and that all surrogacy arrangements, commercial or otherwise, should be illegal and unenforceable. The Weller Committee, which was set up in Victoria and which reported in August 1984, followed the Warnock line. The Victorian Parliament's response to that committee's report was the Infertility (Medical Procedures) Act 1984, which has not, however, been proclaimed. It is the first Act in the world to deal in detail with in vitro fertilisation procedures. Commercial surrogacy is made criminal by it and all arrangements, contractual or otherwise, are made void and unenforceable.

What should be our attitude to commercial surrogacy? Ought we to permit commercial surrogacy arrangements? I must confess that my instinctive reaction is that fees for conception, carriage and birth seem not just distasteful but morally offensive. On the other hand, in the United States of America traffic in commercial surrogacy is allowed. What of the non-commercial surrogacy arrangements? My instinctive reaction here is that in certain circumstances surely those arrangements should be permitted. I give the House the example of a non-commercial surrogate arrangement motivated by love and affection. There is a known case in this country, in circumstances in which conception might have been fatal to the wife, of the wife's sister volunteering for in vitro fertilisation procedures. Should that not be allowed? If one is looking for ancient precedent it is perhaps to be found in the Book of Genesis, Chapter 30, verses one to six. It is quoted by Mr Russell Scott in his excellent book The Body as Property. It reads:
And when Rachel saw that she bare Jacob no children, Rachel envied her sister; and she said unto Jacob, give me children or else I die.
And Jacob's anger was kindled against Rachel: and he said, Am I in God's stead, who hath withheld from thee the fruits of the womb?
And she said, Behold my maid Bilhah, go in unto her; and she shall bear upon my knees that I may also have children by her. And she gave Bilhah her handmaid to wife: and Jacob went in unto her.
And Bilhah conceived, and bare Jacob a son. And Rachel said, God hath judged me, and hath also heard my voice, and hath given me a son . . .
That is perhaps the first example of a surrogate arrangement.

I turn to the second of the three cases to which I wanted to refer. It starkly illustrates the new moral frontiers that we have reached. It is now scientifically possible to take an in vitro fertilised egg a few days after its creation, surgically divide it into two sections and freeze one part and implant the other in a woman's womb, for the conception of a female child then to take place and for that child to grow to adulthood. It is scientifically possible for her then to be implanted with the other section so that she becomes the mother of her own twin. This would never be permitted but the scientific possibility exists.

Let me take the third case. In vitro fertilised eggs can be deep frozen and stored, and Australians perfected this technique back in 1981. Stored eggs can become surplus. What does one do with the surplus eggs? The Warnock and Weller committees thought that research was justifiable provided that the eggs were no more than 14 days old. In the United Kingdom Parliament very recently Mr Enoch Powell introduced a private member's Bill which would outlaw all forms of research into in vitro fertilised eggs, and that has received a very wide measure of across the board support in that Parliament. Yet I understand that the benefits of research could be vast-for example, a cure for Down's Syndrome. I have not the least idea what the answer should be, but the dimensions of the moral questions with which these new techniques confront us are universal and must be dealt with on a national basis.

Two things are necessary: Firstly, a Federal inquiry at the highest level, bringing in those who are wise, not simply in scientific matters and techniques, but also in ethical and moral questions; and secondly, a code that should apply throughout this country. Newness, the complexity and the dimensions of the questions we have to face would caution us to hasten slowly. Whilst we must hasten slowly, we must begin urgently because it is essential that this question be addressed and be addressed deeply and that we come up with solutions which are wise, which are understood and which are beneficial.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Marriage Amendment Bill is of great importance in the electorate I represent because, although 35 per cent of the marriages in Australia are between a party who was born overseas and an Australian, in my opinion at least half the people married in my electorate were born overseas. Great problems arise out of common law because a marriage celebrant-be it a minister of religion or an authorised celebrant-has no way of knowing whether the person being married is an alien, is domiciled in Australia, or is a permanent resident here. This legislation is essentially to simplify the procedures for authorised celebrants. The legislation recognises overseas marriages and facilitates the marriage of Australians, residents of Australia, and persons who are in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In introducing this legislation the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) mentioned the Hague Convention on the Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages, which is really an informal arrangement whereby a number of countries come together in the Hague every four years. Australia joined this group in 1976, and I noted in the Canadian Bar Review a list of the countries forming the conference. These include the Arab republic of Egypt, Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Czechoslovakia and so on. Other Western countries include the United Kingdom and the United States. These conventions with which we are dealing came out of the Thirteenth Conference on Private International Law in 1976. I congratulate the Government for bringing them forward because they are extremely important in this day and age when many Australians marry overseas and many know that they may have trouble getting their marriage recognised in this country. I believe that the provisions of the Bill will be of great assistance, not only to the marriage celebrants but also to the officers of the Attorney-General's Department.

The legislation goes on to deal with the fees paid to authorised marriage celebrants. The Opposition has circulated an amendment which I know the Government will oppose because the Government has consulted with the marriage celebrants and is prescribing certain fees. I know that the House will support the Government's provisions there. The part of the legislation which has attracted some interest is the question of legitimacy of children. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has mentioned in vitro fertilisation at great length. Only State governments can legislate on legitimacy and the Commonwealth can agree only when a State government acts in this area. The legislation is really irrelevant to the question of legitimacy. I do not wish to delay the House because I know that the Minister is keen to have the legislation passed tonight. I commend the Bill to the House and congratulate the Minister for bringing the legislation forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand in this House representing the National Party of Australia. Whilst I applaud many of the principles contained in the Marriage Amendment Bill, which is to bring into effect the provisions of the Hague Convention on the Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages, it is important to scrutinise very carefully anything brought before this House by the Hawke socialist composite Government. I use the word 'composite' because of the rag-tag combination of warring factions which constitute that unhappy entity. However laudable the substance of the Bill may be, Australians must appreciate that the Australian Labor Party is once again ripping up, indeed working to wreck utterly, the spirit of the Constitution by bringing in this Bill in this manner.

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that when we return to government after the next election any future proposed treaty be subjected to proper scrutiny as to its constitutional implications by a joint committee of this House and the Senate. In addition, there must be extensive consultations with each of the States before any such proposed treaty is executed. As honourable members may be aware, the United States Government by law cannot enter into treaties without the consent of the United States Senate. We on this side of the chamber consider the Crown, federalism and the Constitution--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am reluctant to interrupt the honourable member but he is diverting from the Bill. He is talking about ANZUS, the Crown and the United States Senate. I ask you to bring him back to the legislation.
—I ask the honourable member for Fisher to make his remarks relevant.

—The point I was making was the the Hague Convention is a treaty. As such, the Commonwealth, by bringing in this legislation, is able to obtain additional legislative power which would not normally be available under the Australian Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: There would appear to be a bipartisan approach to the principles to be enacted by this Bill; however, as honourable members on both sides of the House realise, the price of liberty, especially with the Labor Government temporarily in control, is eternal vigilance. Any act of Parliament concerning marriage is of fundamental importance to this House and all Australians. Therefore, I was somewhat concerned over implications which could have followed from the title of this Bill. It is supposed to be the Marriage Amendment Bill, but thankfully it is not intended to amend marriage itself, as one might think. One never knows with the socialists.

It is apparent that the Marriage Act 1961 is to be the subject of surgery, although fortunately it will not be subjected to Labor's Medicare fiasco. The Bill seeks to ensure that wherever possible there should be similar rules throughout the world concerning marriage. It is to be hoped that the international community as a whole will embrace the Convention as time goes on. As an honourable member on this side of the House mentioned previously, at this time very few countries have embraced the Convention. It is a direct result of Australia's immigration policy in recent years that large numbers of people involved in Australian marriages are overseas born. In fact, as the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) mentioned, just two years ago, in 1983, 35 per cent of all marriages in this country had at least one party born elsewhere. The percentage may well now be higher. There is a possibility, however remote, that some of those marriages could be invalidated because of the fact that one party may not have been a British subject, an Australian citizen or domiciled in this country. It is important, wherever possible, to ensure certainty in relation to such a basic matter as marriage. Speaking generally, if this Bill is passed our law will provide that, subject to certain exceptions, the law of the jurisdiction where the marriage was effected will govern the validity or otherwise of that marriage.

There is mention in the Bill of the Family Law Act and I am pleased because it provides me with a brief opportunity to comment on the Act and the Family Court of Australia. In addition I am worried about the apparent lack of respect by some people for the Family Court, and we must look at the reasons. Of course, like all others in this chamber, on both sides, I utterly condemn violence. Prior to Gough Whitlam, Senator Lionel Murphy--

TALK.START.PARA: —A dreadful duo.
—They were a terrible duo; I thank the honourable member for Parkes for his contribution. Prior to them and their infamous band of socialists embarking on Labor's family law experiment--
—A point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Offensive words were used against a justice of the High Court who is a former member of another place, and I ask that you rule them out of order.
—I regret that my attention was diverted and I did not hear the alleged offensive words. I will leave the matter to the honourable member for Fisher.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Prior to Gough Whitlam, Senator Lionel Murphy and their infamous band of socialists embarking on Labor's family law experiment, matrimonial matters were dealt with in an impartial, respectful and just manner by the ordinary legal system. Previously, for decades, perhaps for more than a hundred years, the begowned and bewigged judges presiding from elevated positions in the court-room in a relatively anonymous way decided the same highly charged, emotive issues which are now the responsibility of the Family Court. Decisions by and large were accepted by the parties. They felt they had a fair go. Those judges did not go in fear of their lives; they were not locked up for their own protection.

—A point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I know the honourable member is a new member, but debate on the Family Law Act is irrelevant to this legislation. This Bill deals with the Hague Convention which has nothing to do with the Family Law Act. I do ask you to draw the attention of this new member to that fact.
—I do not know that the honourable member has gone far away from the content of the Bill before the House, but I ask him to become relevant.

—The judges did not go in fear of their lives. They were not virtually locked up for their own protection. In view of the recent tragedies and other problems, the Government should consider either phasing out the Family Court as we know it and reinvesting jurisdiction in the State supreme courts or, alternatively, remodelling the Family Court along traditional supreme court lines. I do not intend to impugn the integrity of Family Court judges but a decision on this matter is one of top priority. Without wanting to be facetious in any way, it is in every sense a matter of life and death.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to see that the Bill provides for a widening of marriage education. Anything that can be done to reduce the present unacceptable degree of marriage breakdown should be encouraged. I believe that counselling and marriage education are vitally important and that moneys should be set aside to help people discuss their problems and resolve them if possible. Probably against my own pecuniary interests as a lawyer, I have not hesitated to refer matrimonial clients to a local clergyman or other qualified person for counselling, because if difficulties can be isolated, then with good will and effort a marriage can get over its rocky period and be saved. It is important that every opportunity be taken to preserve marriages where this is practicable.

I am totally opposed to any suggestion that the Government should deny ordinary Australians the right to enter into contracts with marriage celebrants for the provision of services at fees to be agreed by the parties. I support the amendment which is to be moved by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). It may be helpful to have a scale to be used as a guide, but citizens ought not to be denied the right to make their own arrangements with marriage celebrants, some of whom are more popular than others. Perhaps they do their job better, but in any event they are more popular. I would like people to be able to make their own financial and contractual arrangements with marriage celebrants. Personally, I would like everyone to want to be married in church. However, a farce is made of a Christian marriage service when people arrange for the same because of the niceness of the church buildings, the decor or the surroundings. Therefore, marriage celebrants have a role to perform and they and their clients ought not to be denied one of the basic tenets of free enterprise-the right to agree on a charge for services to be rendered. We on this side of the House are absolutely against this proposed further infringement of personal liberty by the Hawke socialist Government.

In summing-up, undoubtedly the passage of this Bill will cause some benefits to flow to the community, but there are also grave constitutional implications which could amount to a subversion of the Constitution by stealth. If the Federal Government wants to increase its power at the expense of the States, it should do so only with the concurrence of the Australian people through the referendum procedure. On balance, this Bill would have to be described at best as a mixed blessing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am astounded. If honourable members opposite want to go on with the debate, we will go on with it tomorrow. I am taking only a few minutes. Speakers on this side have cut their times by arrangement, and the Opposition talks as if there had been no arrangement.

The amendment to be moved by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) is not acceptable. It relates to the parties being able to negotiate their own arrangements in respect of fees paid to marriage celebrants. I think it is a matter of note that in 1979, when the honourable gentleman's party was in power, it altered the fees by way of Schedule. There was not any of this dramatic agitation that we have had this evening, as if this were some socialist measure trying to regulate the rights of parties. In fact, when honourable members opposite were in power in 1979 they could well have done away with setting fees. Such a procedure gives some recognition and stability to what would be an appropriate fee. I do not think it in any way prevents parties from paying more if they want to. I cannot understand the sort of nonsensical argument put this evening that people can pay only the amount set down. We are not for one minute suggesting that the parties could not pay more. Therefore, the amendment does not have the validity that the honourable member claims.

SPEECH.PARA: Some worthwhile contributions were made about uniformity of legislation relating to in vitro fertilisation. I acknowledge that this matter has been on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General for some years, but we cannot get agreement from the States. Legislation has been enacted in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, so there is some uniformity. I want to make it clear that the Government, by simply referring to these procedures, is not making any statement about approval or disapproval of the procedures, because there is a lot of public concern about them. Nevertheless, we have to recognise the fact that they are being used and on that basis some attempt has been made, and we will try again, to get Attorneys-General across Australia to agree. I emphasise, and I ask honourable members to take note, that the States which have agreed are New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. It is not altogether fair to make accusations that the Commonwealth wants to enter the field, but I think everyone would agree that there should be some uniformity of legislation affecting marriage and the family. We are not getting the co-operation that we need.

If one looks at family law in respect of custody and the children of the marriage, one will see an emphasis on State rights. In respect of this matter the Family Law Council is currently finalising a report on a sub-committee chaired by Mr Justice Asche, a senior judge of the Family Court, on the wider social issues raised by the new procedures which have been the subject of debate. It is expected that this report will be available in the near future. Other matters were raised in respect of the Family Court which I do not want to waste time on, except to say that the Family Law Council has prepared a report which I hope to table in the next 14 days. It relates to a number of issues which the Parliament may want to debate. Again let me make the point that the family law legislation was a non-party measure in which people with a wide-ranging set of views participated.

I think the only other matters of significance were the questions raised about the two new family law centres. They are pilot centres which will try to assist people to identify problems which may lead to matrimonial breakdown. Again, we have a problem in respect of excessive litigation in very few adversary combat cases-the figure is 12 per cent-relating to property and custody. This litigation is costing a lot of money. These centres will be beneficial in two ways if they can get the parties to agree without that sort of combat: Perhaps the parties can reach reconciliation, and let us hope they can; if they cannot, at least the bitterness of extensive and costly litigation can be avoided.

I do not want to say any more about a number of matters raised, except to point out that some were outside the ambit of the Bill. I appreciate the co-operation that has been given. I make the point that a number of the matters that have been raised will be the subject of future reports or further deliberation at meetings of Attorneys-General.

I cannot see any real value in the amendment. It is a method of indicating to marriage celebrants that they have a responsibility and a special privilege. We believe it is appropriate to determine a reasonable fee by regulation. I make the point that there is plenty of precedent for that because the regulations have been varied from time to time. I thank honourable members for their participation and I hope they will support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 15, page 5, omit proposed sub-section (4), substitute the following sub-section:

'' '(4) Nothing in this Act shall prevent a person, not being a minister of religion, who is authorized under sub-section (2) to solemnize marriages, from contracting with the parties to an intended marriage for the payment, for the solemnization of that marriage by that person, of a fee that exceeds the fee prescribed by regulations made under section 120 that is applicable to the solemnization of that marriage by that person.'.''.

In the course of the second reading debate I made plain, I think, the purpose of the amendment which I have now moved on behalf of the Opposition. I feel I must repeat what I said, albeit briefly, because the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) seems to be under some misapprehension as to what the point is. It is a very simple point. We need to keep only two facts in our minds to understand that point. The first fact is this: the Marriage Amendment Bill proposed by the Government provides, and I am paraphrasing here, that a civil marriage celebrant is not-I repeat, not-entitled to demand payment for the solemnisation of a marriage by that person of a fee that exceeds the fee prescribed by regulations made under the Act. In other words, the Bill provides that a civil marriage celebrant is not entitled to charge a fee over and above the fee which the Government fixes as the appropriate fee, even if the parties who are free and consenting adults agree on a separate, a different, or indeed a higher fee.

The second fact is that the amendment moved by the Opposition provides-again I am paraphrasing-that nothing in the Act shall prevent people from contracting to pay a fee which exceeds the fee provided by the regulations. That is a very clear issue and the Attorney-General should understand what the point is. However, instead of replying to the argument, what the Attorney-General has done has been, first, to say that he cannot see any value in the amendment and, secondly, to show that he simply does not understand the issue. He says there is nothing wrong with fixing a fee. What is wrong with it, and this is the part which is new and which has not existed in the Act before, is that the Government's Bill says in effect: 'We will fix the fee for a civil marriage celebrant, but not only will we fix the fee, we will make it illegal for a civil marriage celebrant to charge over and above that fee even if the parties who are free, consenting adults agree on a different fee'. It is really no wonder that the Attorney-General does not understand this because members of the Labor Party do not seem to understand that free people, on matters touching their personal relationships, often want to come to free arrangements and bargains between themselves without a government dictating to them and telling them what the charge will be. What we say on this side of the House is that people are free to name their own arrangements. If there is going to be any restriction on the arrangement which free people wish to make, freely entering into a bargain, there must be an overwhelming case made out as to why that restriction on their freedom is to be written into legislation.

We say that no case has been made out in this particular circumstance that we have before us tonight as to why the rights of parties to enter into an arrangement freely between themselves should be restricted. Indeed, it is worse than that in this case because the Government has not even attempted to show such a case. There is nothing in the second reading speech tending to show why there should be this restriction on individual freedom.

I have already spoken on this issue in the second reading debate and I do not wish to delay the Committee any further. I simply say what I have said because originally it was extraordinary to me why the Government could not understand the difference between us and what the amendment is designed to achieve. I hope that as a result of what I have said it is now clear to the Government. I hope that on this occasion it will allow, despite the fact that it is a socialist Government, this small modicum of freedom for individual people.

Brown) makes the point that there seems to be some real problem in this legislation authorising that the fee to be charged is that specified in the regulation. This has basically been the situation. In fact, honourable members will notice in the second reading speech that there can be ancillary charges for items such as flowers and music. I do not think that a lot of emphasis can be placed on the fact that there is a prescribed fee in the regulation when it can obviously be altered by arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal now of a fee always being the subject of identification in the regulation was to indicate to people that there was a fee and they would at least have knowledge of it. I have no doubt that in the spirit of private enterprise they might want to shop around. If it is left on the basis that there is not going to be any charge prescribed, the view is that excessive charges may be made by people for no valid reason other than that they feel they have a select clientele because the authorisation of civil marriage celebrants is basically related to geographical position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is to say it is excessive?
—I am not saying that the fee is excessive. I make the point that the fee has been set periodically on a rising scale.

In other words, it is thought that civil marriage celebrants might agree among themselves to charge a much higher fee than would normally be reasonable.
