TALK.START.PARA: —Answering a Dorothy Dix question in the House today, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a totally unwarranted attack on the economy of Queensland and the economic management ability of the Queensland National Party Government. Not only was his attack unwarranted, but also it was completely wrong in its assumption. The fact is that the Queensland economy has a basic underlying strength which provides a sound basis for sustained growth in the longer term. Quite obviously, I cannot in the time available provide a major resume of the Queensland economy, but I can more than adequately put the lie to the Prime Minister's statements.

SPEECH.PARA: For a start, the Prime Minister conveniently ignores the fact that primary responsibility for economic management in Australia rests with the Commonwealth Government. State governments have to dovetail their policies in with Commonwealth policies. Further-this is especially so in the case of export oriented States such as Queensland-they cannot isolate themselves from the world economic situation and international market prospects. The fact is that under this Federal Labor Government free enterprise States have been saddled with such things as full wage indexation and ever increasing taxes and charges. This Labor Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. If the Prime Minister gets his way, he will surpass even his own record and try to cripple the free enterprise States all the more.

Despite the burden of a Federal Labor Government-a Government bent on mass socialisation and nationalisation-and despite what the Prime Minister would have us believe, Queensland is showing a well above average performance compared with the rest of Australia. Latest available figures show that private capital investment in Queensland represents 17.4 per cent of the Australian total. Housing completions account for 24.5 per cent of the Australian total; total building represents nearly 30 per cent; and exports, 23.7 per cent. Queensland consistently accounts for a major share of Australia's mining and agricultural exports-22 per cent of mining output; 23 per cent of agricultural output; and 22 per cent of total Australian exports in the 1982-83 financial year, which is the latest year for which figures are available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

In addition, although Queensland, with 12 per cent, has a less than proportionate share of total Australian manufacturing output, manufacturing industry in Queensland is far less dependent on tariff and quota protection than that in other States, especially New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. Also, if the Prime Minister cared to look at some other statistics, he would discover that over the four years ended 30 June 1981-the latest figures available-Queensland's Budget performance consistently exceeded that of every other State in Australia. So much for the allegation of economic mismanagement.

The Prime Minister based his argument almost entirely on the fact that Queensland's unemployment rate is above average when compared with that of the rest of Australia. Perhaps he is not aware of the fact that the State is addressing the challenge of unemployment through a high level committee which is expected to report within the next week or so. I bet that it will come up with some better long term suggestions to meet the unemployment problems than this Federal Labor Administration could even dream up. Furthermore, Queensland has undertaken a $600m capital works program which it expects will create more than 12,000 man years of additional employment directly and about 40,000 man years of employment totally.

Yet again this Labor Prime Minister has demonstrated what he is really about. He is about deceiving the Australian population and trying to compete with that great Premier of Queensland, the Hon. Joh Bjelke-Petersen. The Australian people and the people of Queensland are aware of what he is up to. Mr Speaker, in quite simple terms that you will understand, what he talked about in this Parliament today in answer to a dorothy dixer is simply rubbish and it just will not wash.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will send a copy of a recent Queensland study of the economy to the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh). I rise to advance the case for a rethink of the present system of delivering government services to the public, especially in the less populated areas. To this end I propose a pilot scheme to set up what I am calling a one stop community services centre. I refer honourable members to the North-West One Stop Welfare Centre in Coburg. This concept is ideal for small towns, especially for country service centres. I see it as the ultimate in decentralised servicing. I see it as ideal for the developing mining towns of central Queensland. I believe that it is the ultimate in taking government administration to the people. If this type of system were implemented I am sure our constituents would benefit greatly. It would mean that services such as pension matters with the Department of Social Security, immigration issues, employment matters, legal aid, veterans' affairs, and Medicare could all be serviced at one point in these less populated regions, without the need for a huge pyramid of government departments. It could also involve State services and even local community services.

SPEECH.PARA: One could add to these centres child care, consumer affairs and so on, but the main thrust would be to provide an information service. It would also have broader aims and objectives, the first being to improve the ease and effectiveness of public access to government services. Honourable members must appreciate that many people miss out on their entitlements and benefits, in part because they do not know they exist and in part because they cannot get to those services and benefits. Such a system would also mean a shift in the forms of referral and decision-making, a shift closer to the clients or public affected. It would also improve co-ordination between the officials responsible at the local level.

The role played by these centres could be virtually unlimited: The provision of information, help with the filling out of forms, the reviewing of claims, the receiving of claims, and making representations when there are complaints. It could be a multi-faceted role. As I have already stated, we could add to these activities advice on entitlements and eligibility and information in regard to appeal processes. We could have an extension of the present agency approach that we see in the Department of Social Security. That Department provides welfare officers in some country towns for some 10 hours a week and those people provide an excellent service, but it is not good enough. It is a single service and covers only pensions from the Department of Social Security. There is a need to have an amalgamated approach where very senior officers can be appointed in small townships that may have only 6,000 or 7,000 people but a catchment area of 20,000 or 30,000. Biloela in central Queensland is typical of those types of townships. I see this as decentralisation in decision-making. It is a system that can work. The agency systems has worked and the welfare officer system has worked. I assure honourable members that this pilot scheme I am advocating, which has already been approved in Coburg, will work.

I urge the Government to undertake a number of pilot schemes. Obviously, from a parochial point of view, I would like to see them in my own region. In the central highlands we have a number of new mining towns. The populations are only small, sometimes 2,000 people, sometimes 1,700 people, but they are scattered over an area of about 250 kilometres. If one township was selected to be a community services centre that township could service all the people in the immediate area and perhaps 20,000 or 30,000 people over the wider area. Dysart is a typical example of the central highlands where this could happen. Biloela is an example in the Callide-Dawson Valley. I am sure honourable members have typical examples as well. Biloela, for instance, is a small town but it has a huge catchment area of some 21,000 people that it services. Dysart is typical of the small town in the midst of many others. Consideration must be given to ways of upgrading the delivery of Commonwealth services in country and rural areas.

Consideration must also be given to people who simply cannot afford to make contact with the provincial and capital cities. I ask as well that consideration be given to the use of the 008 phone call system. Governments in the past have used this when implementing or introducing a new scheme, but then that facility is stopped. At this moment I understand that whilst the Health Commission cannot introduce Medicare centres everywhere, the 008 facility would solve most of the problems. I urge the Government, through the various Ministers, to consider this matter. I suggest that the local personal approach is far better, however, than the phone call and it is for this reason that I urge that serious consideration be given to the one-stop community services centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my first speech on my return to this place after a 20-month enforced exile. I think it is a pity that we are not given the privilege of making a maiden speech on such an occasion. The first thing I noticed here is that the rights of the back bencher, the private member of this Parliament, seem incredibly to have been eroded during the period I was away-and it seems to be getting worse. Notices of motion are no longer read in the Parliament. Tonight private members have been deprived by the curtailment of the adjournment debate. This is one observation I make on returning to this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not here to speak about that tonight; I am here to speak about something that I believe is of vital importance and which should be of tremendous interest to every Australian. As Australia heads towards 1988 I am sure we all look forward to the many great events that will be undertaken around the nation during that tremendous year. I would like to focus the attention of the House on what will probably be Australia's greatest event, and that is the advent of Expo 88 in Brisbane during that year. Expo 88 promises to be the biggest event in Australia's history. It will run from April until October 1988 and will bring the focus of the world not only to Brisbane or Queensland but indeed to the whole of Australia. I have to express some concern about what seems to be the old Australian syndrome which is already starting to creep into some areas of the Press. Already we read that Expo 88 is likely to be a disaster, that nobody is really interested in it and nobody will come.

During my 20 months of enforced exile from this place I had the privilege of serving on one of the Expo 88 committees. The forward planning and the interest shown from around the world in Expo 88 will ensure that it will be one of the greatest events in our history. Expo 88 has the theme of leisure in the age of technology. Never before, I believe, has an exposition had such a broad theme, and never before in such early stages has there been such tremendous interest, not only from nations around the world but also from big corporations. I was delighted to read today in the Brisbane Press that Australia Post has already undertaken to provide postal facilities there which it believes will exist in the year 2010. I think Australia Post should be congratulated for that move. The British Government has already made an announcement that it will be exhibiting at Expo 88. The Japanese Government has now indicated it will be there too, and the Soviet Union will exhibit at Expo 88. As well, some of the world's greatest corporations will be on show. What does this mean to Brisbane, to Queensland and indeed to the whole of Australia? The initial survey that was undertaken for Australia's bid for Expo 88 indicated that that exposition will attract no fewer than 8 million visits during the six-month period that it is on. This means that Australia's international tourist figures will be boosted by an estimated 792,000 during that period.

Yet the ramifications of Expo go much wider than just that six-month period during which it is to be staged, because for a full 12 months before and six months after Brisbane will be very much a hive of activity. In Brisbane at the moment we can already see the evidence of what is being done in terms of job creation, with two international hotels already under construction and another three to be built by the time Expo opens in April 1988. They are very significant figures.

The point is that Australia will be very much in world focus during that time. I believe that it is up to all Australians to give their absolute support in the lead-up to Expo and during that event. For example, it amazed me that the Australian Tourist Commission had not even listed it as one of Australia's bicentennial events until recent weeks. That is an absolute disgrace. I commend the Federal Government for the support it is giving to the Queensland Government and to the whole Expo authority to make sure that it will be one of the great events that Australia has seen and that it will be very much the focal point of Australia's bicentennial celebrations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House once again to the assets test which is one of those pieces of legislation which are callous, iniquitous and quite unfair to many people in Australia. I draw attention to a few example which have arisen in my electorate. One is an elderly couple in the Devonport-Latrobe region. He is a 66-year old farmer who is crippled and who lives with his wife. His son works that property and has done so for 15 years. He has four children. The average farm income, according to his accountant, is $5,420 for the last five years. He works a 100-acre farm which was valued at $100,000 on government valuations. When he submitted this for the assets test, officials from the Department of Social Security decided that it should be valued at $125,000. That is 25 per cent more than what he had claimed.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequence for this family is that this man's pension has now been cut from $118 a week to $35.30 a week, with no fringe benefits. It is said that this Labor Government is a fair Government, interested in equality and equity. Yet we ask the elderly people of Australia, such as those in the family to which I refer, to pay for their electricity, food, petrol, clothes and paint their houses out of $35.30 a week. That is what the assets test is doing to people. The son has done his best to earn other income by renting other properties. There is no way that he is able to afford to buy the property because he has worked on his parents' farm for a pittance over several years.

I have another example within my electorate in which the officers of the Department of Social Security have included not only the normal assets as part of the assets test, but also what they call 'business value'. I do not think I have heard of this before. They have worked out that this person has $1,406 in his bank account, house contents worth $4,000, a motor vehicle worth $3,000, and his property value has been assessed at $87,462. As well as that, the Social Security officers have put on his form what they call 'assessed business value'. In other words, they seem to be interested in another aspect of this person's assets. It has nothing to do with what he owns. They seem to want to estimate the value of a person's good will in regard to his business.

The assets test is setting people against one another. Many people in the small rural areas of Australia believe that people who live in the cities get off scott free, with substantial money tied up in their own homes. Yet when people in rural areas own something to the value of $100,000 to $150,000, they lose their pension. There is no sense of justice or equality in the assets test. It was supposed to hit the wealthy people. These people are not wealthy. There is no way that anybody could imagine that they are wealthy. I challenge the Government to do something about it. I was pleased to see in the paper today that the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), as Chairman of the Caucus Primary Industry Committee, has approached the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in regard to this matter. I hope that the Government bears in mind the needs of the people of this country because their needs are great.

I also challenge this Government to return the extra $60 million-odd which it will get from the assets test over and above what it expected to get to the people who are in receipt of pensions. The Government said that the reason it introduced the assets test was that it would have more money to give to people who are in receipt of pensions. This type of legislation is iniquitous. I hope that the Labor Government in future will think through the ramifications before it introduces any further legislation of this nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) outlined some of the Government's achievements. In particular, he drew attention to the fact that since we have been in government we have created 360,000 jobs, compared with the miserable effort of the coalition parties which created 340,000 jobs in their seven years in government. Yet I believe there is an outside chance that we may not be able to reach the target of 500,000 jobs that we promised in three years' time. If the Government fails to reach that three-year target of 500,000 jobs, it will be because of the efforts of the Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who is sabotaging his economy. I believe he is doing that because he has been reported as seeking to destroy the Federal Government as his last great achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of us will remember what happened in 1975 when the Queensland Premier took advantage of the death of a Labor senator to send to the Parliament a renegade senator who helped to oust the Whitlam Government-a democratically elected government. Sir Joh seemed to think that was all right. He cannot do that any more because we have changed the provisions by way of referendum so that if the Parliament loses a senator of any political persuasion he must be replaced by a person from his own party. That is a vindication of the people's perception of what was fair. It was something that the Queensland Premier never thought of in 1975. How could he get back at a government that is so successful, has lowered inflation, created jobs and has the economic growth on the board that his Government could never achieve? What he is doing is scuttling the Queensland economy because it is on the downhill run anyway.

There is a clever diversionary tactic here. If one looks at the figures for the Queensland economy-notwithstanding the statistics put out by the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh)-one finds that the present rate of unemployment in Queensland mentioned by the Prime Minister is 11.3 per cent. In Australia it is 8.3 per cent. That is absolutely terrible. Queensland has the highest rate of unemployment in Australia's history. Bankruptcy of small firms in Queensland is up by 27 per cent. A stack more businesses are going to hit the fence because of the recent Queensland power dispute. The figure of 27 per cent is a record. Per capita income in Queensland is the lowest of any State on the mainland. The only people who beat the Queenslanders are the Tasmanians. Both States have conservative governments. As we all know, Sir Joh has taken on the unions. One starts to wonder why. The Chairman of the Griffith University School of Social Industrial Administration, Dr Peter Coaldrake, is reported in an article in the Age as saying-he may be right but I do not think he is:
Sir Joh's latest battle was much bigger than maintaining Queensland's power supplies or achieving a cherished goal of crushing the union movement (through draconian no-strike legislation).
The article continues:
Dr Coaldrake said that with a State election scheduled within eighteen months the power crisis had given Sir Joh something to divert attention from the badly performing Queensland economy.
'The power crisis provides a wonderful way whereby the state Government in a political sense can deflect blame for the economy from itself to the unions.

One can see from a mile away what Sir Joh is trying to do. The economy in Queensland is going down. So Sir Joh picks out the unions and takes on a battle with them. He has a convenient scapegoat, but as the Queensland economy goes down it subtracts from the Australian economy. As we have said, we will create 500,000 jobs even if we have a lead boot in Queensland. If all States in Australia pull together the goal of creating 500,000 jobs certainly will be within our reach. What is the Queensland Premier doing?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.
—He is doing something. An article in the Age on 15 March stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke Petersen, could not wait to get on board the USS Buchanan, the warship banned by New Zealand in the ANZUS treaty controversy, when it berthed at Brisbane yesterday.
With demonstrators being arrested outside wharf gates, the Premier diverted a flight back from Roma-

I will be charitable and say that he was on government business. I do not know what he was doing in Roma. However, he diverted his flight to get on the USS Buchanan so that he could greet the captain. Here is what the conservatives love the most: Demonstrators being arrested outside and Joh on board the USS Buchanan.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a loyal Australian.

—Of course he is a loyal Australian. So are we loyal Australians. The ANZUS Treaty has never been in better shape since we came into government. There is no doubt that the Queensland Government is deliberately slowing down Australian economic recovery in an attempt to deny the Federal Government the full economic recovery it has initiated. When we measure Australia's growth at the end of our three-year term we should put in a positive adjustment for Queensland because obviously what the Premier is trying to do is to wreck his own economy, battle it out with the unions and in some way slow down the economic recovery we have started. Not even Premier Gray in Tasmania has the gall to do that. But do not worry, Mr Speaker. We will reach the 500,000 job target without Queensland.

—Tomorrow is cut-over day for the assets test scheme for pensions administered by the Department of Social Security. Of course it was on 14 March that pensions administered by the Department of Veterans' Affairs were cut over to a scheme which has been shown to be shot through with anomaly after anomaly. I support the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and many other honourable members who have drawn attention to these anomalies. I am prepared even to support the members of the Caucus who yesterday revolted against aspects of the assets test which led to a half-baked assurance in the media this morning that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) would review aspects of the assets test. I challenge the Minister for Social Security to come into this House tonight in the ten-minute extension available to him on the eve of the assets test cut-over and explain what time-table he will apply for looking at a review of the anomalies associated with the assets test, as he indicated in the media this morning that he would. There are hundreds upon hundreds of pensioners across Australia--
—Thousands.

—Indeed, thousands of pensioners have been ruined in a very severe way by the application of the assets test. I regret to say that the matter of suicide has been raised. I regret to say further that I am advised of one case where the suicide was related specifically to the introduction of the assets test. It will be an acid test of the assets test to see what is the rate of suicide in the over 65-year-olds for the months of March and April 1985. However, I will not dwell on that.
